Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(6 comments)

Thanks, this is looking pretty good. Please see inline comments. Also, UML2EcoreConverterOptionsDialog will need to be updated with the new options as well. And of course we'll need to bump all of the plugin and feature versions as appropriate (but I can probably take care of that once the code is in).

Is there any urgency on getting these changes into a release? It's rather late now to get it into the March simultaneous release (deadline for release records was February 4) unless we want to push for an exception.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Thanks for the updates, I think we're close to something we can merge now. See my latest comments. Sorry for being so picky, but I think it's important this be done in a way that's consistent with how the other options work. I also had a question/concern about annotating the enum data type with a reference back to the UML element (see inline comments).

Patch Set 1:

This is minimal effort to ensure both the fix for bug 525840 is applied when necessary, and that bug 544578 is fixed.

We have this situation:

1. Java 8 for build, Java 11 for runtime is broken by fix for bug 525840, it used to work without it.
1. Java 11 for build and Java 11 for runtime doesn't work without the fix for bug 525840.

So this change uses the code as it was before the fix for bug 525840 and applies this fix only if the code is not enough to determine the source container.

Note that I've not tested with Java 9, only with Java 11. Let me know if you want this as well, I'll need to fetch a JDK 9 for this.

(23 comments)

Thanks for starting the review :)

"If you would split such a large feature into a series of multiple commits building on top of each other reviewing would be easier."
So i've to start from beginning and i will try do make small commits.

"Could you provide instructions how to configure for a few cases, e.g. configure to use p4merge or kdiff3 as merge or diff tool ?
How to use pre-defined tools compared to how to use custom configuration ?"

"Here the first round of comments which came to my..."
I agree with all of your comment, see my answers. I will try to follow the other code in EGit/JGit, it's big, but will see...

"I think reading of tool configuration from .gitconfig should be moved to JGit"
Yes, i know, see my comment in the issue/bug description. I will move it to JGit - It took me some time to understand how to get, modify and build EGit and i've no idea how i can do the same with JGit and how to deploy it together with EGit -> use the new API implemented in JGit from EGit... but i will search for more instructions...

"I suggest to create dedicated config classes similar to..." 
Thanks for showing the way i can go :)

"why do we need to show a modal dialog asking if the merge or diff tool should be opened when the user just said he wants to open a diff or merge tool ?"
I tried to implement the workflow like it's done in CGit, so if "difftool or mergetol.prompt = true" in your config i've to ask the user before starting etc. just set it to false and will start without asking, but it's then not possible to abort if there are lot of files... i've to think about how to made it usable and not block eclipse etc.

"I tried to configure p4merge as diff and merge tool (on Mac) and found that this modal dialog isn't closed when p4merge comes up, this modal dialog sits on top of p4merge and doesn't react on mouse or keyboard events (see http://imgur.com/phBCGtg). Maybe my difftool/mergetool configuration is wrong ..."
I'm working with Windows at work and with Windows and Linux at home, will try to reproduce. But anyway i've to change the way how the external tool is calling from Eclipse. I saw some examples in other Eclipse plugins. I know some way from my EasyShell plugin. Blocking of Eclipse is not good/right now and i know it should be fixed. My solution is very basic, it just had to work fro our migration from ClearCase to Git :(

"add tests"
yes sure, i want to add tests, but actually very difficult to understand the way to do it with such big plugin like JGit + EGit, i will investigate the test framework used...

Thank you again for the review and very usable comments, i hope to start rewriting it soon...

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(23 comments)

thanks for working on this :-)

Wow this is a huge change, hence it took me a while to start reviewing it ...
If you would split such a large feature into a series of multiple commits building on top of each other reviewing would be easier.

- Could you provide instructions how to configure for a few cases, e.g. configure to use p4merge or kdiff3 as merge or diff tool ?
- How to use pre-defined tools compared to how to use custom configuration ?

Here the first round of comments which came to my mind while looking into this change, I didn't yet look into all details:

- avoid unrelated formatting changes, this helps to keep changes smaller and reduces chances for conflicts with other changes
- don't print to System.out for logging, use slf4j API in JGit and Eclipse logging API in EGit instead
- externalize texts shown to the user (UI texts, error messages, log messages) and use MessageFormat to create texts containing parameters

- I think reading of tool configuration from .gitconfig should be moved to JGit, I suggest to create dedicated config classes similar to RemoteConfig or DiffConfig, e.g. DiffToolConfig and MergeToolConfig (common parts could go in a common base class) this provides a typed API to access the configuration details
- there is already some support for running external processes/commands in JGit, see how GitHook and its subclasses use FS. OS dependent handling of calling external processes is handled in subclasses of FS
- ideally the code for exposing external merge and diff tools should be implemented in a way so that it could also be integrated with jgit command line (this is bundle org.eclipse.jgit.pgm), maybe it's even easier to first implement the basics in jgit and integrate them into jgit command line before integrating them with EGit's UI
- I would consider to implement this in a more object-oriented way similar to what we did for GitHook and its subclasses, i.e. instantiate the tool classes based on and instance of the respective jgit config class (e.g. pass DiffToolConfig to constructor of DiffTool class) and implement execution of tools in a method of the respective tool class, common code could go in common superclass. I think this would be easier to understand and maintain than a util class with a ton of static methods

- why do we need to show a modal dialog asking if the merge or diff tool should be opened when the user just said he wants to open a diff or merge tool ? I tried to configure p4merge as diff and merge tool (on Mac) and found that this modal dialog isn't closed when p4merge comes up, this modal dialog sits on top of p4merge and doesn't react on mouse or keyboard events (see http://imgur.com/phBCGtg). Maybe my difftool/mergetool configuration is wrong ...

Patch Set 3:

> Next try. PackageAdminImpl used the ModuleContainer to find
 > bundles. The retrieval of the ModuleContainer looks a bit strange.
 > I figured out that I could get it from the DebugOptionsListener by
 > looking into org.eclipse.osgi.internal.framework.SystemBundleActivator.start(BundleContext).

Other than using the static convenience method ModuleContainer.createRequirement() there is no need to access the ModuleContainer.  All you need is the FrameworkWiring object which can be adapted from the system bundle.

For future reference.  Nothing should really need direct access to the module container for the live Framework instance.  It has low level constructs in it that would be dangerous to play around with on the ModuleContainer that sits behind the live Framework instance.  With that said, an easy way for normal bundles to get the running Framework's ModuleContainer would be:

ModuleContainer container = bundleContext.getBundle().
        adapt(org.eclipse.osgi.container.Module.class).getContainer();

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> To be more specific, here are some questions:
> 1) Which specific thread executes code when problem occurs?

Some internal MSIE thread.

> 2) Is it actually a problem to access widget's fields from a different thread?
> 3) If .getParent() is a problem, can you just save the reference to it beforehand?

Widgets are not thread safe, all widget access must happen on the GUI thread. Granted, races are unlikely here and maybe even impossible, but it's not the reason to break this API contract.

> 4) Is it possible to ask Windows not to do that in a separate thread?

No. It's an undocumented implementation detail.

> 5) What are the consequences of "default processing" ?

Default processing means automatic zone assignment by MSIE.
WebBrowser control overrides MapUrlToZone to adjust security zone for about:blank pages only. Unexpected cross-thread call never happens for about:blank, therefore MapUrlToZone doesn't need to do anything if it's called on the wrong thread.

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Still I don't think that it should be implemented this hackish way.
> 
> Instead, I suggest the following approach:
> Refactor 'IE' class to tell 'WebSite#iInternetSecurityManager' whether it should return IE.URLZONE_INTRANET or do the default processing.
> 
> This should eliminate the problem in reliable way (I'm not so sure that resorting to default processing will not cause new problems). As a bonus, this hack will also be eliminated:
> 
> (IE)((Browser)getParent().getParent()).webBrowser;
> 
> This doesn't really look like a good way of accessing data to me.

This patch is simple, straightforward and reliable. Your hypothetical refactoring of IE would be none of these.

To begin with, there's no way to guarantee correct threading from the outside, because the problem in question is MSIE implementation detail.

Patch Set 1:

To be more specific, here are some questions:
1) Which specific thread executes code when problem occurs?
2) Is it actually a problem to access widget's fields from a different thread?
3) If .getParent() is a problem, can you just save the reference to it beforehand?

5) What are the consequences of "default processing" ?

Patch Set 3:

Still I don't think that it should be implemented this hackish way.

Instead, I suggest the following approach:
Refactor 'IE' class to tell 'WebSite#iInternetSecurityManager' whether it should return IE.URLZONE_INTRANET or do the default processing.

This should eliminate the problem in reliable way (I'm not so sure that resorting to default processing will not cause new problems). As a bonus, this hack will also be eliminated:

(IE)((Browser)getParent().getParent()).webBrowser;

This doesn't really look like a good way of accessing data to me.

Patch Set 4:

> To begin with, there's no way to guarantee correct threading from the outside, because the problem in question is MSIE implementation detail.

Probably some misunderstanding. I was trying to say that every browser control has its own 'iInternetSecurityManager'. At any given time, browser control is either on about:blank page, or not, and it knows this via internal variables (ie.isAboutBlank && !ie.untrustedText).

This means that at the same time when (ie.isAboutBlank && !ie.untrustedText) is changed, IE could tell 'iInternetSecurityManager' what is the current state.

This will eliminate all threading issues, eliminate the original problem, and also eliminate the need for this rather dirty code:
(IE)((Browser)getParent().getParent()).webBrowser

This sounds like a rather simple and reliable patch to me - with nearly the same effort, it removes problems instead of implementing workarounds for them.

Am in favor of this patch, could find below guideline from MSDN regarding usage of "INET_E_DEFAULT_ACTION":
Use the default security manager for this action. A custom security manager should only process input that is both valid and specific to itself and return INET_E_DEFAULT_ACTION for all other methods or URL actions.

MSDN link for the same:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ms775145%28v=vs.94%29?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

See comment inline.
Also, it'd be great to provide some unit tests for that; and in case of Files, maybe to fully delegate to FilePropertyTester which has a more reliable way to decide content-type (also looking at file content which for example allows to refine the XML content-type to sub-content type)

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I think it's important to take file content in consideration for this case. For typed XML or JSON where the schema discriminates the content-type (using the ContentTypeDescriptor stuff), this is a key concept that shouldn't be ignored here.
It's important to try retrieving the contents for a given editor input.
If there is no better way, I suggest you move this property tester to org.eclipse.ui.ide bundle where you'll be able to reference the main subclasses of iEditorInput to access more details and get better results.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

The patch makes TCF symbols server build to fail:

cc -I. -Isystem/GNU/Linux -Imachine/x86_64 -g -DENABLE_arch_x86_64 -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -Wall -I../agent/. -I../agent/system/GNU/Linux -I../agent/machine/x86_64 -DUSE_canonicalize_file_name=0 -DUSE_enum_ptrace_request=1 -DUSE_strlcpy_strlcat=0 -c -o obj/GNU/Linux/x86_64/Debug/tcf/framework/cpudefs.o ../agent/tcf/framework/cpudefs.c
../agent/tcf/framework/cpudefs.c: In function âread_reg_bytesâ:
../agent/tcf/framework/cpudefs.c:680:46: error: âSysRegisterDataâ undeclared (first use in this function); did you mean âRegisterDataâ?
             uint8_t * r_addr = (uint8_t *)&((SysRegisterData *)frame->regs)->data + reg_def->offset;
                                              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                                              RegisterData


The patch does not make sense: SysRegisterData cannot be reused across different types of CPUs - size of structure depends on number and sizes of CPU registers, it cannot be reused for registers of other debug contexts (like peripheral devices).

> These functions do not use any static or global variables, so sharing them across such interfaces is safe.

These functions use "typedef struct SysRegisterData", which is bigger problem than static or global variables.

Patch Set 1:

Don't you need to include an implementation in the pgm feature then?

Patch Set 2:

> > Don't you need to include an implementation in the pgm feature
 > > then?
 > 
 > Sounds reasonable, but I'm not an expert in that area. I was
 > actually wondering if the plain cli.jar already needs those
 > dependencies, and if so, where to add them (the BUILD file is of
 > unknown format to me).

The BUILD file is for the bazel build. Interestingly the bazel build already has only slf4j as dependency for o.e.j (no log4j), and pgm has a dependency on commons-logging, whereas the maven build uses log4j. I wonder if the bazel build is correct. I thought one needed a bridge between commons-logging and slf4j?

I also wonder what happens in Eclipse. What logging implementation is used there? As long as log4j is included in o.e.j, there is at least that, and it also appears to be active (message on startup about there not being a logger for FS). If log4j is no longer included, what happens at startup, and what logger should be included by whom?

Patch Set 3:

> * commons-logging is a transitive dependency of Apache httpcore and
 > httpclient
 > * if we don't include a logging implementation in pgm it can't
 > write logs
 > * in Eclipse log4j doesn't really help to emit JGit logs in the
 > Eclipse logs
 > since Eclipse itself has its own way of logging,  I think the right
 > solution would be something like this change started by Gunnar
 > https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/96277/ "SLF4J Binding for the Eclipse
 > Platform Log"
 > which we could restore and finish. AFAIR the idea was to provide
 > this in the platform
 > since there are other plugins using slf4j which would also benefit
 > from such a bridge
 > to Eclipse platform logging

Logging in Java is a crazy mess. Too many different frameworks and back-ends. "You are in a maze of twisting little passages, all different".

For newer Eclipses, there might also be a bridge from sfl4j to OSGi logging: [1] The problem AFAIK is that slf4j wants only _one_ logging back-end, and it'll complain if there are several. And some other plug-ins bundle other back-ends. I think m2e brings logback, and I would have to look again what Xtext brings. But having _something_ "standard" in platform would be great.

Apache MINA sshd, BTW, uses slf4j. The fact that I don't know how I could redirect slf4j logging to the Eclipse error log worries me a bit -- I don't know how to do a low-level tracing switch like I did for JSch.

[1] https://www.eclipsecon.org/europe2018/sessions/integrating-slf4j-and-new-osgi-logservice-14

> > > Don't you need to include an implementation in the pgm feature
 > > > then?
 > >
 > > Sounds reasonable, but I'm not an expert in that area. I was
 > > actually wondering if the plain cli.jar already needs those
 > > dependencies, and if so, where to add them (the BUILD file is of
 > > unknown format to me).
 > 
 > The BUILD file is for the bazel build. Interestingly the bazel
 > build already has only slf4j as dependency for o.e.j (no log4j),
 > and pgm has a dependency on commons-logging, whereas the maven
 > build uses log4j. I wonder if the bazel build is correct. I thought
 > one needed a bridge between commons-logging and slf4j?
 > 
 > I also wonder what happens in Eclipse. What logging implementation
 > is used there? As long as log4j is included in o.e.j, there is at
 > least that, and it also appears to be active (message on startup
 > about there not being a logger for FS). If log4j is no longer
 > included, what happens at startup, and what logger should be
 > included by whom?

* commons-logging is a transitive dependency of Apache httpcore and httpclient
* if we don't include a logging implementation in pgm it can't write logs
* in Eclipse log4j doesn't really help to emit JGit logs in the Eclipse logs 
since Eclipse itself has its own way of logging,  I think the right solution would be something like this change started by Gunnar
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/96277/ "SLF4J Binding for the Eclipse Platform Log"
which we could restore and finish. AFAIR the idea was to provide this in the platform
since there are other plugins using slf4j which would also benefit from such a bridge
to Eclipse platform logging

Patch Set 1:

> Can this be owned by the Repository instead of being a singleton?

Generally there is no need to fine-tune this option per repository basis. The mmap-based approach to read index file is simply always better than reading index into memory, and the question is only to infrastructure, since dealing with mmap files is JVM-specific (it differs a little between Oracle/OpenJdk, and between 8 vs 11).

I can imagine no criteria for this option to be repo-specific

Patch Set 1:

> In other words, I'm suggesting something like dependency injection.

As far as I see, singleton and factory approach is common to JGit code base. 
Using dependency injection will not make debugging easier since all implementations share the same code actually

 > An alternative would be to always mmap, unconditionally.

It's not easy to code JVM-agnostic approach for mmap files, since cleanup is different in oracle, openjdk, 8 and 11.
I'd rather move here step-by-step and contribute that after this factory is merged

We cannot be sure that the devices targeted by extenders can support extended-remote but we can provide a useful error message at launch time if an attempt to launch with extended-remote fails due to lack of support in the GDB server or a special requirement of the device which is implemented via doRemote(). We are not breaking any existing launch configurations, only providing an opportunity for some users to create a non-functional launch configuration.

I think this would be preferable to creating new versions (eg OpenOCDSocket2, GenericDevice2, ...) of all existing IGDBJtagConnection implementations in the CDT repo.

Patch Set 1:

Well, if you are not going to accept the patch then you have to abandon it and close the bug as wontfix.

Still IStartup is the only way to automate things when  - actually eclipse - starts. Typically this is the workbench. We do have users that rely on services getting started by that extension, hence the request that EASE runs them. I agree that this is not ideal regarding the initial concept behind IStartup.
On the other hand I cannot tell users that some projects are violating a basic eclipse concept and therefore EASE does not support them. We use a pragmatic approach to solve a real world problem.

Regarding the proposed patch I thought it would be trivial and do no harm to the EGit project. Only other option would be to disable the EGit Startup by using preferences. Would Egit still work correctly then? (Also in 'full UI' mode?)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As I said on the bug, I'm not convinced. The javadoc on IStartup says
clearly "Plug-ins that register a startup extension will be activated after the Workbench initializes", and on earlyStartup() "Will be called in a separate thread after the workbench initializes. Note that most workbench methods must be called in the UI thread since they may access SWT."

IStartup is a UI concept, and EASE should simply not call IStartups when it doesn't initialize a Workbench at all because it wants to do headless things. EASE is violating the contract by calling IStartups before a Workbench is initialized.

Patch Set 1:

Compare bug 50164. IStartup is a UI concept, loading and calling it will typically also activate the bundle containing it (BundleActivationPolicy: lazy), and the Activator may try to do more UI things (mylyn.team.ui and mylyn.tasks.ui, to name just two). Since you want a headless setup calling IStartup just doesn't feel right, and adding tests in IStartup that check that the workbench is running when the contract already promises that it is doesn't feel right either.

Patch Set 4:

What I am looking for is something in between. The tree should be created synchronously, that is a fast operation. Then, async, the files should be checked for existence. So when the tree is initially created, it should have the existence flag set to "unknown", and once the async code runs it should set the flag to exists/not-exists. Then the viewer should be refreshed, explicitly passing the node that is updated to the refresh method of the viewer so that not all the tree needs to be refreshed.

Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

Hi Baha, I think you have code in threads backwards. It looks to me that the tree is created in the job, but the existence check is in main thread. If so, you need to invert that, or at least move existence check into job too.

One extra thing that needs to be done is cancel job if a new call to displaySourceFiles is made before the last one finishes. This can happen if the user is single stepping quickly.

Patch Set 3:

(9 comments)

Looks good so far. 

In addition to the notes below. I have seen that GDB often returns duplicate, or near duplicate, entries. The full paths will be identical, but the name may be different e.g. something like:

file=../name.c,fullname=/path/to/name.c
file=name.c,fullname=/path/to/name.c
file=/path/to/name.c,fullname=/path/to/name.c

but because we (rightly) clean it up on display, we end up with duplicate entries.

> If I would want auto-activation everywhere, I would also want it in Javadoc.

Right.

Good question. I don't know yet. There could be some other use-cases where this option is useful, such as someone using a custom content-assist and who doesn't want auto-insert.

In any case, it's clearly not for 4.10!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

1. For invalid null pointers caused by programmer error, "fail fast" behavior is preferred.
Such cases should be handled by segmentation fault or (optionally) assert().

2. For backward compatibility, we don't allow C99 style of variable declaration placement.
Variables have to be declared at the start of a block.

Patch Set 1:

> ... logic should be replaced by assert(ctx).

No, "should" is wrong word. In some cases assert() might improve readability, but in most cases it is already obvious that null pointer not allowed, so adding assert is pointless, and depending on segmentation checks is fine.

> ... since they are additions to already existing condition sets

Does not matter. Null pointer checks are required for run time error reports, like result of malloc(), but not for programmer errors.

If invalid pointer is a programmer error, it should be investigated and traced back to where it originates. Then offending code should be fixed. Checking for null on receiving side does not fix the problem, only makes it more difficult to locate.

The changes appears to make programmer errors less visible - this should be avoided.

Patch Set 1:

OK, the "if (!ctx) ..." logic should be replaced by assert(ctx).

Are the other pointer checks acceptable? I would think so, since they are additions to already existing condition sets.

Patch Set 5: Verified-1 Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I only had time to look on one of your FBs. I think there are some serious issues that should be fixed.

Furthermore I noticed that you are connecting to the device on every event or for the INIT you are even opening two times a connection to the device. This is a very resourceful slow process. Wouldn't it be better in your case to open a single connection to your device on init and reuse this while the FB is initlized?

Patch Set 6: Verified-1 Code-Review-2

(8 comments)

I still have major issues with your code. First of all the copyright headers are not conforming to the Eclipse regulatoins. 

Furthermore I see a lot of code duplication. Can this be factored out into more generic functions in your moxa.h/.cpp.

Especially, as pointed out in my last review, when you move the connecting code to your init function and keep the socket open until deinitilisation half of your code could be removed. I think this is even easier when considering martins comment about utilizing Forte's socket abstraction. Then your code would even be platformindependant.

Patch Set 20:

Thank you with your patience with us. From the general quality this code is now much better.

However there is a point that I would like to discuss with you. The problem is that you have waiting calls in your FBs. This can severely disturb the execution of FORTE. So normally, I think I mentioned this previously, we would implement an dedicated external event handler with an own thread how would take all this blocking code and manages the responses. One step futher would be to impelment the new IO concept. Hoever for that we currently have little examples. Therefore I think for you it is important that you can access your devcies and do your exeperiments and I assume that this is now working for you. What I'm not sure if the 4diac repo is currently the right place for this code.

Patch Set 6:

> (1 comment)

Up to know it looks good. But you are deleting files in the working tree and that scared me. We should be very careful when deleting files. And in this case you are not deleting file <f> because you found it in the list of files which the algorithm detected to be deleted. But you derive from the fact that we want to write <f>/<g> the the file <f> has to be deleted. In 99% of the cases that's ok but I want to doublecheck that we don't overlook cornercases where we accidentally delete a non-versioned file/symlink/submodule.

Patch Set 6:

Here is one problematic situation I detected. 

I tested with 
	native git: 2.18.0 on MacOS
	Jgit old: a historic master: 91021cb66
	Jgit new: patchset 6 of change 127968: commit 14368c257 

Git operation to be tested:  âgit checkout <MERGE>â (default checkout without options)
	Situation before the checkout:
		MERGE: folder âpâ containing file âfâ with content âmergeâ
		HEAD: folder âpâ containing file âfâ with content âmergeâ
		Index: nothing
		Working tree: file 'p' with content 'working'. (Same problem comes if we have a executable file or symbolic links with name 'p' here)
	Checkout results:
		Native Git: Checkout successful! Index and Workingtree unchanged.
		JGit old: Checkout failed. Therefore Index and Workingtree unchanged
		JGit new: Checkout successful. But the file âpâ in working tree was deleted. The working tree contains the folder âpâ and itâs child âfâ with content 'merge'

Here we delete during a normal checkout content of a user which is not yet saved somewhere. That should be fixed.

Good news: I tested with scripts a lot of structural different situations (nearly 4000) and of course there are a lot of situations where jgit behaves different from native git
but at least your change makes things worse only in this case.
I'll run the tests also for situations where we 'git checkout -f ...', 'git checkout -- <path>', 'git reset ...'

Patch Set 6:

When testing a 'git checkout -f <mergeCommit>' commit operation I see this change only improves the situation. In the case where HEAD and MERGE contained the same folder p, index contained nothing and workingtree contained a file,executable or link this changed made jgit behave like native git. +1 for this change and the "checkout -f operation"

Patch Set 6:

... and for command "git reset --hard <mergeCommit>' (the use case you intended to fix) it looks also very good. Dozens of cases where JGit now behaves like native git and whenever JGit behaves different it is at least the same wrong result as before. So +1 for the 'reset --hard' case.

Whats left over to fix is that we in very few cases this changes triggers deletion of  unsaved content in the working tree as mentionend in one of my previous comments.

Running the load tests on dev environment, only slight increase in response times (around 2% in average).

Some operations are more affected in big repositories:

 * Listing branches: ~11% slower
 * Listing tags: ~10% slower
 * Listing self-groups: ~10% slower
 * Listing parents of a project: ~8% slower

In summary: As many have pointed out, the difference ioping show is not that big but running Christian's test shows a big gap between local FS (xfs in our case) and NFS.
The performance impact of this change is not that big in Gerrit 2.14, at least in our environment.

Patch Set 4:

I was concerned about the performance also and tested a little bit our NFS based servers. To be honest: I could not 
see in real world a big performance penalty due to this change and the follow up change. I think access to NFS is
so slow that the extra filesystem calls we do here don't effect the runtime substantially.

So I wrote a small test program which tests how expensive it is to instantiate a File object and check existence of the
file with and without the NFSFile abstraction. On non NFS machine we see that this is 40% to 50% slower with the NFSFile abstraction.
But on NFS instantiating a File object and checking existence is 100 times slower (in our environment) than with a local
FS and the extra checks introduced by NFSFile don't influence performance measurable.

My proposal for this: for NFS environments this change makes sense, but for local environments we have to make sure
not to use NFSFile.

Test Code: https://gist.github.com/chalstrick/1407328309efdbe4f1e258e6bc02470a

Results when executing the Tests against a JGIT based on change 123297 (commit 082767048274ac69459895c132c827f760aa8a52)

> ###### NFS filesystem
> java -jar /tmp/PerfTest_NFSFile.jar
Repo created in /mnt/perm_storage/persistent/git_web/git/tmp_1528379190155
Instantiated 100000 File objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 29905 ms.
Instantiated 100000 NFSFile objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 31227 ms.
Instantiated in a repo with CONFIG_KEY_REFRESHFOLDERSTAT set to true 100000 NFSFile objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 32294 ms.
> cd
> ###### Local EXT3
> java -jar /tmp/PerfTest_NFSFile.jar
Repo created in /usr/sap/ljs/home/tmp_1528379463416
Instantiated 100000 File objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 504 ms.
Instantiated 100000 NFSFile objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 928 ms.
Instantiated in a repo with CONFIG_KEY_REFRESHFOLDERSTAT set to true 100000 NFSFile objects for existing files and checked explicitly for existence (found 100000 files) in 697 ms.

If you wonder why the performance (at least in this test programm) is better when you explicitly turn on the checks: I thinks thats because if no config files contain CONFIG_KEY_REFRESHFOLDERSTAT we have to inspect all possible three config files (repo,system,global) to come to this conclusion. If the repo config file already contains CONFIG_KEY_REFRESHFOLDERSTAT we don't have to look at there.

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> I was concerned about the performance also and tested a little bit our NFS based servers. To be honest: I could not 
> see in real world a big performance penalty due to this change and the follow up change. I think access to NFS is
> so slow that the extra filesystem calls we do here don't effect the runtime substantially.
> 
> So I wrote a small test program which tests how expensive it is to instantiate a File object and check existence of the
> file with and without the NFSFile abstraction. On non NFS machine we see that this is 40% to 50% slower with the NFSFile abstraction.
> But on NFS instantiating a File object and checking existence is 100 times slower (in our environment) than with a local
> FS and the extra checks introduced by NFSFile don't influence performance measurable.
> 
> My proposal for this: for NFS environments this change makes sense, but for local environments we have to make sure
> not to use NFSFile.
>

Thanks, Hector for sharing this initial feedback.
Can you run as well an 'ioping' from staging to the NFS volume and then to a local volume?

That would give us an indication of the performance of your NFS server.

If NFS is very slow, the %CPU increase is not dramatic, because you are constantly waiting for I/O. However, the end-user response times may be impacted.

In our case, the NFS volume is very fast (only 50% slower than the local one) and that's why the %CPU went up but the overall end-user response times remained flat.

Additionally, we are on v2.15 and NoteDb accesses are ~ 90% of the API calls to loose refs. You guys have packed refs and that's why you don't have so many calls.

Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

I did some further tests on our GerritHub.io production to see if refreshing the stats before reindexing would have helped to have a consistent last update TS on the refs loose objects (NOT this fix specifically but the same refresh hack on the parent dir of the loose ref): the result is that *sometimes* triggers the NFS cache refresh but most of the times it doesn't, at least on our system.

Having instead the hack called *all the times*, even if was giving more trouble to the server, was more effective.

Removing then my -1, because the performance penalty on Gerrit v2.14 is not significant. For Gerrit v2.15 (aka JGit >= 4.9) we would need a completely different solution. I am investigating the idea from Martin to read the loose ref all the times unconditionally.

Patch Set 1:

> As a caller, I would expect that implementations would use
> my monitor to report the progress back.

It is up to the receiver to determine how frequently they report progress. Leaving the monitor unused is legal and not an API contract violation. However, obviously it is undesirable. In most such methods we'd want to add progress reporting later and for this reason we should not add "this monitor will be unused" to the API contract.

> But these two implementations, CompositeRepositoryApplication
> and MirrorApplication, break this contract by not using my
> monitor at all and not reporting any progress.

No part of the IProgressMonitor contract promises that any progress will be reported. It promises that, if progress should be reported, it will be reported to that instance and specifies the rules for reporting such progress. But completely ignoring an IProgressMonitor is valid and would respect all aspects of the API contracts.

> Again, as a caller, I would be surprised by this fact.

Yes, it's suprising. Also undesirable. However, it's not an API contract violation. It's just a feature that hasn't been added yet. We should not create a contract that promises not to add the desirable feature.

> Am I missing something about the IProgressMonitor's JavaDoc?

No, but you're assuming something that isn't there. IProgressMonitor doesn't make any promises to actually report any progress. This is desirable, but not part of the contract.

Patch Set 7:

This analysis is a proof of concept, very useful to Abder right now:

1- It shows we can use the TraceAdapter to transform a perfectly normal analysis into a marker event source

2- It transforms some segments into a MarkerEvent, as Matthew also did in the futex analysis/control flow view

3- This one does it without touching the view at all

Now. How should we handle that for TraceCompass in general? Shall we rather have an interface IRegionOfInterestSource that any other analysis can implement to provide bookmarks? One common class (that implements ISegment) to handle all markers/bookmarks/regions of interest that analyses/plugins can extend.

Or just commit this as one source for now, and maybe make it customizable later, the way Matthew's in&out patch does (right-click trace, define the event representing the bookmark, etc).

Because right now, this patch is very very custom. I don't think it can be useful to anyone but Abder in the current state.

Patch Set 9:

@Bernd, could you elaborate on your need and use case? This patch is the result of quick prototyping for a very specific situation for Abder. But it would be interesting to have a more production-ready solution.

> I believe we'd need a new extension point in debug. Something like

Your idea works well for LSP I think because you have not an AST on client side. In JDT context, I'm using AST of JDT and I visit variables inside the methods which is enclosed by stack frame. But perhaps it will work well with good performance?

I gave a quick look at this proposal of API and it looks good to me and it seems pretty useful for actual implementation in debugger support (I'd like to use it ASAP in LSP4E for Debug Adapter Protocol). 

I'm a bit unsure about the grain: should this be an API provided in Debug, or a feature internal to Debug which would apply to all debuggers (making API internal and having a preference for enablement in all debuggers)? Patch Set 1:

With http://git.eclipse.org/c/platform/eclipse.platform.debug.git/commit/?id=aa4768fe77615b457e4eb3aca5f0dd22b1ed7da2 . the debug framework contributes a generic debug variable hover to the generic editor whenever the ITextSelection can be adapted to an IVariable.
Maybe we could reuse this strategy for a default contribution to generic editor? That said, it could be another iteration. JDT does need an API anyway. But rather than an abstract class, it could be a class that receives a BiFunction<IDocument, Integer, List<T extends IVariable>> as input in the constructor so it's easier to separate concerns (prefer composition over inheritance).

Patch Set 1:

> If I understand your idea, you will loop for each line of the document and call the extension point to get variables to display. In JDT CodeMining I visit AST, not the full lines of the document. But perhaps it will work well with good performance?

It's an implementation choice. The API doesn't tell when to visit the lines or not. But I understand what drove you to this idea.

Maybe it's better to assume that the document and stackframe is passed in the constructor for instance, so that it becomes clearer that one can place a documentListener to get the variables whenever doc changes and just return the value in getVariablesAtLine(...) instead of having the impression that they need to compute the resolution at each invocation?

Patch Set 1:

By the way, it seems also very important that the StackFrame gets passed as a parameter of the method/class as the same document can be involved in multiple debug sessions simultaneously and we'd only want to see the values of the IVariables for the currently selected session.

Patch Set 1:

The real problem sits deeper. In AbstractTreeIterator.pathCompare(), GITLINKS and TREES do not compare equal. As a result, a TreeWalk will first return (GITLINK for index and HEAD, and null for working tree), and next (null for index and HEAD, and TREE for working tree). So we see this as a remove GITLINK followed by an untracked empty folder (which will be filtered out by the IndexDiffFilter).

Which is of course wrong. I suspect Paths.lastPathChar() has to handle TYPE_TREE and TYPE_GITLINK the same.

Patch Set 10:

> I just gave this patch a try. It works very nicely!
 > 
 > A few question: How is the performance for you? I'm seeing a very
 > variable delay of 1-5 secs when I delete/add files to a folder. But
 > I am running this on a MBP 2007 so that might be part of the reason
 > ;)

Thanks for the testing. Could you please activate the debug tracing for the refresh? (both "debug" and "refresh" tracing options must be checked for org.eclipse.core.resources plugin)? 

Could you then try some changes in your terminal, printing the date on it and see the average between the change and the notification in the console?

$ date && echo "xxx" > /path/to/project/file.txt

You should see something like this in your Eclipse log

Thu Oct 06 11:58:09 CEST 2016 - [OSXRefreshProvider (1)] OSXRefreshMonitor: refreshing 'P/aProject'

By comparing it to the date on your terminal, you should see the effective latency. 

I've configured the refresh monitor to use a latency of 1 seconds (to avoid consuming too much cpu: the FSEvents framework do event coalescing during this latency time; it means that we are called less often).

If you see more than 1 seconds (what I experienced myself on a MBP 2015 with SSD), it would mean that the age of your machine is probably part of issue :)

Also, if you feel that we should retrieve the native events more often, I'm ready to change the latency value.

 > If I create project foobar, switch to the Terminal and delete (rm
 > -r foobar), I don't get the prompt "The location for the project
 > has been deleted. Delete 'foobar' from the workspace?". But if I
 > refresh explicitly the project (F5), then it comes up. I would
 > expect the auto-refresh to behave just like if I pressed F5 to
 > refresh. I'm not sure if it's really an issue with this
 > implementation though.

That was a bug. I did not handle properly project deletions. The new patch set (11) does that now. Thanks for finding this!

If I create project foobar, switch to the Terminal and delete (rm -r foobar), I don't get the prompt "The location for the project has been deleted. Delete 'foobar' from the workspace?". Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Good first start.

What's interesting in this patch is the integration of machine learning in Trace Compass: starting from an analysis output and generating bookmarks from ML results. Whether the results are meaningful is for now not that relevant, as it is more a proof of concept of using deep learning with a trace. This work can serve as basis and inspiration for all the people working with machine learning.

Patch Set 1:

To access the preference, Variables View -> toolbar menu -> Java -> Show Step Result. If this is not visible enough, I'll try to add it directly to the toolbar. In that case it should only be visible if a Java debug context is available.

I'm not particularly happy with the changes in ViewFilterAction. The class doesn't abstract the persistence of the preference; it works directly with a IPreferenceStore that is supplied by extending classes. The original preference for bug 40912 is stored in IEclipsePreferences, so we require some changes. Other possible solutions:

1. Move the preference to the instance preference store, instead of storing it directly in IEclipsePreferences. This I think would mean API breakage, since JDIDebugModel.PREF_SHOW_STEP_RESULT is public and is not internal.
2. Fully copy the necessary code from ViewFilterAction to the new action.

If we stay with this solution, I would like to get better naming suggestions.

Patch Set 5:

> One point also to consider is that generally for views, the
 > settings are not retained if a view is closed and re opened. Like
 > for Package explore I add a filter. close and open PE again, the
 > filter setting will not be retained.
 > But here as this toolbar will update the Java Preference, it will

Right, sorry I've missed this comment.
What we definitely NOT want is that user turn this setting ON, debug a bit, forget about the change and next time wonder why debugger is so slow.

So we may really don't care here about writing the preference to the store *from a view*, just remember it for the current session.

Patch Set 5:

> BTW.: this feature is in eclipse
 > for more than a year and  the only complaints I have seen where
 > related to a bug caused by jacoco.(Bug 531706). 

Not sure if I understand you - we are coming from bug 533702, which IS reported now because people in real world scenarios hit exact this the problem. This was in our product, but only because we upgraded recently to 4.x Eclipse. Before that we were running 3.x for years. Please note, that the adoption rate of Eclipse is not as fast as we can ship releases - many organisations are still running Eclipse 3.8 because it just works.

 > *Nobody* has come
 > up with a duplicate or a test case  for Bug 499339 (Improve
 > performance...)

Bug 533702 comment 7 is the simplest, reproducible test case one can imagine.

If you want a real word scenario: put a breakpoint on line 1093 in org.eclipse.e4.ui.internal.workbench.swt.PartRenderingEngine, run Eclipse SDK in debugger in  and try to step over the "createGui" code inside the for loop

for (MWindow window : theApp.getChildren()) {
	createGui(window);
}

On my modern i8 machine I need ~30 seconds without "show result" and ~4 minutes with "show result". I guess most of the users simply give up and blame their code and not the debugger.

Patch Set 2:

Mykola, thanks for the patch, but I'm not completely convinced that I should merge it:

What kills it a bit for me is the use of the mapping/lambda expressions here. I like lambdas when they can replace inner classes or complex mapping expressions. In this case though, I find them to make the expressions hugely less readable. 

As for Optional itself, I see a huge benefit in its use for public API. For purely internal use, it's offset a bit though by the more complex expressions for essentially the same thing - it's still a reminder to check for null, so that's still a good thing.

Given that, one could of course go back to just using regular ifs and ternary expressions as before, just with Optional. 

I'm a bit sceptical if that's still a good use of Optional though, or if we just leave it with the regular null-check that I already added, and get started with Optional by introducing it at the API level in MPC 2.0 - which I intend to kick off in the next weeks.

Patch Set 3:

I see several problems that would need to be solved here:

* resetting HEAD to HEAD~ should most definitely not be done while we're rebasing or in a rebase/merge conflict state.
* when the commit runs, it'll run with "amend" true. That assumes that HEAD is on the commit being amended, not on its first parent. (That's the source of the "missing parent commit" mentioned in previous commits.)
* The remembered commit to be amended probably should be re-set if HEAD changes in the meantime.

Patch Set 3:

One more item: the commit button should be disabled while the soft reset runs. Otherwise who knows what will be committed.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Playing more with this, I don't think changing HEAD is the right approach. It actually changes the current branch, and we'd have a ton of use cases where we'd have to make sure we undo this before doing anything else.

Patch Set 2:

Hm, ok, I get your point.

Ideally, we would have different subclasses of this minimizer for the different comparison types: comparison with a remote (behavior suggested in this change), a comparison of models in two projects (using the project-relative URI), or a comparison in the same project (using only the file name). Maybe we could extend the minimizer extension point so that it supports enablement expressions for the registered minimizers (for the different use cases listed above)?

At the same, I think the biggest risk is that we have false-positives (even if it is very unlikely). This is worse than starting the comparison where we wouldn't technically have to (as we'd had to do if this is merged). Anyway, I think the impact might be rather limited.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

This way of functionning was not an oversight but a planned behavior.

In the case of local comparisons, resources with the same name will be located in different folders. The minimizer using the full URI will thus never detect identical resources. This is why we were using the name only.

I'd say that remote comparisons constitute the bulk of the use cases, but that might break existing consumers of EMF Compare... I'd like to see if we can limit this new behavior to remote comparisons (comparisons with at least one remote side), otherwise this will likely have to wait for a new major version of EMF Compare.

Patch Set 2:

I see that I had commented the same thing on the attached bug :).

I wanted to completely overhaul the current behavior of the "cascading" filter (actually, I wanted to remove that filter entirely in its current incarnation and use a feature of the comparison model instead ("cascading" diffs could thus be using the refinedBy/refines couple of references to indicate that they are "under" another... or something of the sort)) which would have forced us to make a major version. I couldn't take the necessary time to specify and implement that though so I don't think there'll be an EMF Compare 4 this year unless some other changes introduce breakages.

I'll see how we stand when I'm done looking at and merging the changes.

Patch Set 1:

What is the semantic difference between the NullTimeEvent and a TimeEvent with no value? It's easier to cast to a NullTimeEvent than to TimeEvent and check the value.

And indeed, I think the presentation provider of the FlameChartView maps to the grey color somehow, it has a different behavior: A TimeEvent maps to the control flow's presentation provider and other events, I'm not sure how it gets to grey though...

As for an actual state, the data provider does not return continuous data, only what it has, and the view will "fill the gap" with transparent/invisible states (that's what this patch does).

As a design note, if data providers do not return the "invisible" states, it will be a smaller amount of data, which may have a noticeable impact on the bandwidth of an eventual web application. I think it's preferable to let the views fill the gaps rather than the data provider, but I guess that's debatable.

Patch Set 1:

From your definition, for data provider views, NullTimeEvent is exactly what is needed.

But it is true that the API of the data provider is not clear about it (whence the confusion). We must decide whether 1- it must return data for all sampled times or 2- if sampled time for which there are no value means "nothing/empty/transparent/nodata/dont-wait-for-more".

Whatever is decided should be very well documented, as it will be part of the API of both Eclipse/web/whatever UI.

I personnally vote for option 2

Patch Set 1:

> I think that I implemented the existing data providers with option 1 in mind

That's fine, it's implementation, so 1 is included in 2.

> On the other hand, the BaseDataProviderTimeGraphView does not care if it is 1 or 2.

Actually it does, because it fills the gaps! Does it 1- temporarily fill the gap expecting data later, or does it 2- fill a gap with an empty state because the data there is null? Current implementation is 1, this patch fixes for 2. 

From the user point of view, it makes no difference (shouldn't), but for the implementer of the data provider and view (presentation provider) it does (the proof being the presence of my grey states instead of transparent in the flamechart).

Patch Set 1:

> What is the semantic difference between the NullTimeEvent and a
 > TimeEvent with no value? It's easier to cast to a NullTimeEvent
 > than to TimeEvent and check the value.

A NullTimeEvent is used when you know that there is nothing in a time interval. Normally it wouldn't be necessary to include them at all, but it's mostly for legacy reasons due to the two layers (full and zoomed event list) when you want the zoomed null event to hide whatever is in the lower layer (full event).

The no-value TimeEvent is when you know that there is something but you don't know what it is (because it wasn't sampled). If you have two actual null states with a gap in between, you wouldn't want to use another null in the middle because it would just look like nothing is there.

 > As for an actual state, the data provider does not return
 > continuous data, only what it has, and the view will "fill the gap"
 > with transparent/invisible states (that's what this patch does).
 > 
 > As a design note, if data providers do not return the "invisible"
 > states, it will be a smaller amount of data, which may have a
 > noticeable impact on the bandwidth of an eventual web application.
 > I think it's preferable to let the views fill the gaps rather than
 > the data provider, but I guess that's debatable.

Are you suggesting that data provider sends nothing for 'known' null states? That would work only if we know that we have no gaps at all in the sampling, it would have to be agreed on both sides of the interface...

Patch Set 1:

> A NullTimeEvent is used when you know that there is nothing in a
 > time interval. Normally it wouldn't be necessary to include them at
 > all, but it's mostly for legacy reasons due to the two layers (full
 > and zoomed event list) when you want the zoomed null event to hide
 > whatever is in the lower layer (full event).

Hmm, that sounds a bit confusion/contradicting. What it means is that, once the sampling gaps have been filled, you wouldn't really need to have NullTimeEvent for the time graph drawing, but they are need for the EventIterator that merges the full and zoomed event lists. But this is a separate issue than what needs to be returned by the data provider.

Patch Set 1:

Another thing to consider is that when there is a null state at the start/end of the window range, we need to know the exact start/end time of the null state in order for 'Select Previous/Next State' navigation to work properly.

Hmm, I think that I implemented the existing data providers with option 1 in mind, though still allowing for gaps between states if outside of the sampling. On the other hand, the BaseDataProviderTimeGraphView does not care if it is 1 or 2.

Patch Set 1:

> > I think that I implemented the existing data providers with

well it fills the gaps without checking if the gap is just due to sampling or something that is missing from the sampling. The difference would be that 1. has a default value (Integer.MIN_VALUE) which creates a NullTimeEvent for "NO value" then inserts another interval for missing states to fill the gaps.

approach 2. might lose the "NO value" information in favor of unknown value. We might event have the cases that merge: i.e. a case 1. : |No Value | unknown values | No value would become |unknown value| in approach 2. are we willing to lose this information? (possibly losing the missing states dot in the time graph view and missing some state changes) ??

Hi Fabien, 

First of all thanks for this contribution and sorry for the delay. I'm starting the review now. 
A first feedback after a quick review: we can't depend on antlr-generator for licensing reasons and as such we can't include the corresponding jar into our SCM.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Current pursuit disables camel case matching as SearchPattern.validateMatchRule() says that a match rule is only camel case if no '*' is present in the string pattern.

Change 119827 has dealt with the showing perfect matches first and can be looked towards if any changes will have to be made.

The FilteredResourcesSelectionDialog will also have to be updated to continue highlighting correctly now that the matching resources have been changed, you can look towards Change 115311 for a pointer to that region, but also if you need help there I can be of assistance.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Camel Case (MF matching MakeFile), folder prefixes (test/f matching file.txt in project test), and terminating characters (M*File< matching MakeFile but not MakeTheFile) all do not currently work.

When testing, look at the help page for the Open Resource dialog for examples of all the search types that must function (Open Resource view > '?' button > See also 'Open Resource dialog')

Currently I do not believe it is possible to have a search being both a camel case and regex search, so you will have to implement this.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> Build Failed
 > 
 > https://hudson.eclipse.org/jgit/job/jgit.gerrit/8323/ : FAILURE

RefTreeBatch relies on its bootstrap ref database to be fast. InMemoryRepository uses the efficient InMemoryRepository.batch() when isAtomic() and the inefficient default BatchRefUpdate.execute when !isAtomic(). The default BatchRefUpdate.execute calls cmd.updateType(walk) on all its commands.

Adding u.setAtomic(refdb.getBootstrap().performsAtomicTransactions()) to RefTreeBatch#updateBootstrap works around this. That's a hack.

A real fix would be to make the default BatchRefUpdate smarter. That would also improve RefDirectory's performance.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

It's cool to have the InstallationDialog and the Installation Details command remembering the last tab. This change would remove this.
The change to select the right tab must happen on the link selection inside p2's software installation dialog.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I don't think the proposed patch fixes the issue. If one opens the "What Is already installed?" dialog for the 1st time, there is no guarantee it would show the right tab.
I think a more proper solution would be to introduce a new setInitialTabSelection(String id) method or to add a new constructor allowing to pass an initial tab id; to allow this id to be null or non-existing, and to use the introduced method/constructor to set "10.org.eclipse.equinox.internal.p2.ui.sdk.InstalledSoftwarePage" as preferred initial tab id (I think at this point, it's ok to copy the string, and just have the InstallationDialog logging a warning for unknown id to detect a possible change in the id later).

Patch Set 3:

If you copy the string "10.org.eclipse.equinox.internal.p2.ui.sdk.InstalledSoftwarePage" inside InstallationHandler to pass it as default tab of the InstallationDialog, it shouldn't require any new dependency, internal access, discouraged access, whatever...
It would for sure create a duplication, but I don't think it's too risky here. And in case the string doesn't exist, the dialog could log it so we can easily spot it if tab id changes.

Patch Set 2:

Hi Michael,

My reasoning for the added complexity was that it was the most significant improvement of user experience. In my experience with programming using Eclipse, I felt that the auto activation case was used more often, so I figured it was necessary to include that case in re-activating CA. This feature, I felt, would really help out developers using Eclipse by making it to where they would not need to re-activate CA upon every accidental typo. 

The motivation for this patch was for enhancements to user experience and I wanted to make as many enchancements as possible. For these reasons, I was hoping you would reconsider about using this patch.

Thank you for your time,

Rahul Rajavel

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2 Verified-1

The proposal popup has different functions which get into incorrect states with this patch. Also, the invisible shell damages other features. Just some examples:
- When made invisible instead of hiding, the key bindings for the proposal shell remain active, hence e.g. Ctrl+1, up/down keys etc. no longer work in the editor.
- When made invisible instead of hiding, hovers don't work anymore.
- When cycling (hit Ctrl+Space again) after the shell was made invisible and then going back, the shell is not coming back and even Ctrl+Space no longer works.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2 Verified-1

Sorry for the really long silence.

I quickly looked at it an found two issues, one of which you already pointed out: when there are no proposals and one goes back the content assist popup doesn't come back. It should come always come back to the state before it got closed.

The second one is that the status line font in the content assist popup gets a wrong font (too big and bold).

Patch Set 2:

Hi Rahul, I did fast check of your patch and in general it works (simplest cases tested) but I was thinking about something simpler for this issue. My idea looks like this:

* when CA dialog was auto activated, no change in behavior 
* when CA was triggered manually (Ctrl+Space) don't hide CA dialog in case of 0 available proposals, user will see "No Default Proposals" message. Hitting backspace in case of typo will bring proposals back to dialog.

Similar approach I noticed in JetBrains products and I think it's quite straightforward.

Patch Set 2:

One way or another for me its important to have solution for this issue. If it will be your solution I'm happy with that :)

Regards,
Michal

Hi Norman,

Here are my notes on this change.

I have one outstanding issue, but I don't know what to do about it here, so I am going to open it out to the wider community. That is where to save the settings. At the moment you are saving them in the launch configuration, but I believe there has been some chatter in the past about how that is a problem. There is at least one outstanding bug because the other memory view does save in the launch configuration. See bug 500988.

To resolve this, in the first instance I am going to ask Doug to comment as he has most recently raised the issue, but we might go to cdt-dev for this.

Jonah

So here's the thing: I want in-and-out analyses to have the following features:
* Call Stack
* Flame Graph with outlier lookup
* Stats with outlier lookup
* Function density

At this moment, callstack2 has advantages, and they are a better callstack handling, but in terms of features it has some catching up to do, let's get feature parity and then we can continue on this in XML?

It makes sense to import invalid file, since we can save them, we should also be able to import them, to better edit them.

But when saving/importing an existing file, even if it is invalid, the supplementary files should be deleted. But that should be done not with the invalid file (it won't work anyway), but with the previous valid file, so it should be done before saving/overwriting the file. Also, I guess we should prompt the user before overwriting a valid file with an invalid one. But those are feature/bugs that can be dealt with in subsequent patch.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Martin, I'll agree that these changes can generally be labelled under the "performance" label. However, unless you have numbers ot contradict me, all of these seem like we're not going to win even 1% of the comparison performance time. Unecessary casts are essentially a no-op in java : they're only useful at compilation time and won't use a cycle at runtime. Calling a method that is no more than a getter doesn't use any time (it will appear with yourkit or other profilers because of the instrumentation). The change from a ComparisonSwitch to a long series of if instanceof might be counter-productive : you're changing EMF switch that is essentially an integer comparison for the dispatching to an instanceof test, which is arguably longer.

This uses more time to implement (for you) and review (for me, since changes like these are very easy to get errors mixed in) than the expected gain in performance will bring to the table.

Could you provide me with actual numbers that prove that all of these changes actually bring useful changes? A reproducible benchmark would be best on that aspect.

Patch Set 1:

Rather than alleviating my doubts, your numbers made me extremely wary. The "compare" time doesn't match at all your other numbers, since only the post processing has any kind of visible improvement.

The kind of changes introduced here don't match the kind of difference suggested by the numbers, so I ran the same test suite (PerformanceLargeSuite, which tests on the 'large' model and not the nominal for the record) both with and without the changes.

My numbers are nowhere close to yours, but that's likely explained by a more powerful computer to run them. 

As for the changes themselves, when compared to the numbers, the one impactful one here is that new shortcut in the UMLPostProcessor that does indeed make quite a difference without reducing the readability (in fact, it increases it).

Direct Comparison of Avgs	Without Change	With Change
Compare	10549.67	8806
Conflict	326	344.33
Diff	2083.33	2236.33
Equi	103.33	103.67
Match	897.67	971.33
PostCompareUML	2226	1381
PostMatchUML	53.33	62.33
Req	453	435.67

Patch Set 1:

Sorry I had to switch to another project, I intend to look into this more later. Basically, we want the new shortcut in UMLPostProcessor which is roughly 75% of the improvement this patch produces, and need to find exactly what speeds up the "compare" time. my guess is my initial thought of the CompareSwitch change being counter-productive was off and that is what actually speeds things up.

Patch Set 1:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Martin, I'll agree that these changes can generally be labelled
 > under the "performance" label. However, unless you have numbers ot
 > contradict me, all of these seem like we're not going to win even
 > 1% of the comparison performance time. Unecessary casts are
 > essentially a no-op in java : they're only useful at compilation
 > time and won't use a cycle at runtime. Calling a method that is no
 > more than a getter doesn't use any time (it will appear with
 > yourkit or other profilers because of the instrumentation). The
 > change from a ComparisonSwitch to a long series of if instanceof
 > might be counter-productive : you're changing EMF switch that is
 > essentially an integer comparison for the dispatching to an
 > instanceof test, which is arguably longer.
 > 
 > This uses more time to implement (for you) and review (for me,
 > since changes like these are very easy to get errors mixed in) than
 > the expected gain in performance will bring to the table.
 > 
 > Could you provide me with actual numbers that prove that all of
 > these changes actually bring useful changes? A reproducible
 > benchmark would be best on that aspect.

Hi Laurent,

thanks for your review!
I am usually also not really in favor of using less readable code for a very little performance gain. However, I reran tests.performance.PerforamnceLargeSuite and the performance gain is actually not so little. The average numbers for UML Nominal in each step are listed below. If we sum up all average values, we save about 9 seconds with this change.

             Without Change      With Change
Compare      23151               14663.33
Conflict     622.67              522.33
Diff         3173.67             2930
Equi         143                 115.67
Match        986.67              946.33
PostCompUML  2214                1788.33
PostMatchUML 68.33               62.67
Req          656.67              1033

For your reference, all numbers are here, including min and max:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1fSUFZhJdRiQNWxfvltNkeljjYD8PbESGZSRfua5NeXk/edit

Interestingly, the requirements computation (Req above) has been badly impacted though. So we might want to re-iterate on this particular change.

Patch Set 1:

Thanks for looking into this change again!

Strange that your compare time is much faster than the one on my machine (with and without the change). Still, also on your machine only the compare time shows a speed-up of roughly 1,20x. In total, also on your machine the entire process takes on average 2,35 seconds less than before the change.

Thus, even when the scales are a bit off for the compare time, the basic trend is somewhat similar between your numbers and mine (notable improvement in compare and UML postprocessing).

Please let me know which changes you are willing to merge and which you'd like to omit. I'll then prepare the new PS.

Thanks!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

As commented by Pierre-Charles on https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/60693/
-2 because it seems too risky on a maintenance branch, especially since it does not fix an obvious/major issue. It goes in the right direction, but should be pushed on master first, and stabilized there. Maybe after we're sure it does not cause any regression and after some additional improvement we'll decide to backport it on the maintenance branch.
Some remarks:
ideally, the event should not be analyzed in the UI thread;
this code should not have to access the UI state to test for the active editor. It should probably be the other way around, with a single listener for all editors, and when an editor becomes active it tells the listener "until further notice, I'm the active one". This would avoid the ResourceSetChangeListener to have to access the UI thread to make the test.

The main correction for the initial issue has been merged (see https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/60341/)

Needed improvements for this patch: as proposed by Pierre-Charles:
 . a unique listener (managed by the EditingSession for example, to do the analysis of the event only once (and not in the ui thread)
. we need to add a way to allow each dialect editor to allow it to tell "until further notice, I'm the active one", this might be done in the setFocus(), we might notify the editing session, or the resourceSet might itself listen to editor activation/ selection.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

> Adding a default method is in general a breaking change unless you
 > are very very sure you don't break a client. See the version

I don't fully agree with this statement adding default methods can:
* never break binary compat
* only break source compat if the visibility of the subclass methods is different to the interface ones or the return type differs

Bottom line we break we'd for sure never break consumers, we most likely won't break subclassers.

I'm still -1 on the patch because DialogSettings should implement the methods most likely who does not rely on exception catching

Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

>> Instanceof should be a separate patch.

>No! If we merge this patch, then we loose the warnings, it'll be impossible to get the locations back. Unless we revert this patch. Then, what's the point of merging a patch that is going to be reverted...

This patch fixes one known bug and many potential bugs.

Instanceof and nullable are orthogonal, we can have one without the other.

As for the desire to have instanceof checks, yes, it's good, but it should be done with a source lookup, merging it into this patch would simply instanceof all the fields that were not already nullchecked. Then we will have a mix of nullcheck and instanceof.

The found bug is a big one. This fix addresses it.

Patch Set 6:

I thought about something, what about using Optional<Object> instead of a @Nullable Object for the return type?

Optional is more verbose when we just want to null-check, however it makes it easy to provide default values when the value is null, with .orElse(value) and such. When dealing with trace events, we may want to take alternatives courses of action if some events are not present, not just blow up.

Not sure if it would be worth it, just food for thought.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I believe it's important that once page is loaded, we still offer the "refresh" operation in place of the "Go To URL", like all browsers. This patch fully removes the refresh operation.

Patch Set 1:

In Firefox, I can see a different icon for "Go" and "Refresh", under the hood, it's most likely the same button, but the icon changes according to the state of the browser:
* If currently displayed page URL == URL in the url bar => Show the reload icon (circular arrow)
* If currently displayed page URL != URL in the url bar => Show the Go icon (straight arrow to the right)
I also imagine that the reload actually does thing a bit differently than the go. For instance, reload may invalidate some cache on the page.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Just blocking this for the moment to consult with the team. I want to understand why we used to refer to emfcompare.ecore through a platform:lugin URI instead of platform:resource so that I don't break something by accepting that change.

Patch Set 2:

Refering to compare.ecore and UML.ecore through platform:/plugin instead of platform:/resource was done because there is no need to have the target plugins (org.eclipse.emf.compare & org.eclipse.uml2.uml respectively) in your workspace in order to work on the compare UML integration, or to generate its code. As it stands though, the ecore will either break for the people who have uml installed but not in workspace (with this change) or for people who have it in workspace but not installed (without this change). I'd say both compare.ecore and UML.ecore need to be referred to through their NsURI if at all possible.

The genmodel's change to use MinimalEObjectImpl$Container is not needed (everything is a subclass of Diff which extends MinimalEObjectImpl$Container), but it doesn't hurt. I am surprised though that we somehow re-generated the metamodel but never pushed an up-to-date genmodel (MultiplicityElementChange).

One action required: check the URIs used to reference other ecores from uml2compare.ecore

Patch Set 2:

Hi Christian,


 > Currently each cron script creates a separate Job in the jobs API.
 > These jobs are always visible to the user. Therefore they are
 > visible in the taskbar and the Progress view all the time, even if
 > they are in waiting state. This seems quite distracting to me.
 > 
 > An option would be to schedule() the job with a delay parameter, so
 > you also do not have to poll & check each second.

 Why I did that is that the user is not able to cancel the as long as the job does not run (Maybe I have overseen here something and you have an idea how to get this done better without sleeping).
 What we can do is to set the sleep time higher than one second, but I don't know what is the right interval here. 
 
 > Even better would be to have a single job that tracks all cron
 > scripts, finds the min() amount of seconds to sleep for all
 > scripts, then schedules itself to rerun when the next script should
 > be executed. Upon wakeup it checks which scripts are due and
 > executes them (script execution is asynchronous anyway, therefore
 > the launcher job does not have to wait for script termination).
 > Then it recalculates when it has to wakeup again and reschedules
 > itself for that time. This way we would only need 1 job from the
 > jobs pool and would not stress the framework so much.

I decided to not implement it this way, because 
(1) I do not expect that a user let run many cron jobs in parallel 
(2) It can be more easily be the case, that one job is not triggered at the right time, because another is still running. 
(3) It makes the code more complex.

 > By setting the scheduler job to a system job we can avoid that it
 > is visible to the user.

 I did this. Initial I thought it's a good idea the give the user more transparency to see what running, but maybe it's annoying to see this all the time. I though about to make it configurable, but I hadn't the time to implement this. So now jobs are simply system jobs. 
 
 > I see that you are using the visible jobs to also terminate cron
 > scripts. I would say that users should simply change the keyword to
 > terminate such jobs. in future there will be the possibility to
 > disable keywords from being parsed and executed at all, so users
 > may disable the cron keyword entirely if they do not want it.

Disabling the job by changing the keyword was already implemented, but I removed the code for canceling the job by the user (it's not possible anymore after switching to system jobs).

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Hi Raphael,

I had a closer look and besides some minor changes noted in the source files I have a more generic request:

Currently each cron script creates a separate Job in the jobs API. These jobs are always visible to the user. Therefore they are visible in the taskbar and the Progress view all the time, even if they are in waiting state. This seems quite distracting to me.

An option would be to schedule() the job with a delay parameter, so you also do not have to poll & check each second.

Even better would be to have a single job that tracks all cron scripts, finds the min() amount of seconds to sleep for all scripts, then schedules itself to rerun when the next script should be executed. Upon wakeup it checks which scripts are due and executes them (script execution is asynchronous anyway, therefore the launcher job does not have to wait for script termination).
Then it recalculates when it has to wakeup again and reschedules itself for that time. This way we would only need 1 job from the jobs pool and would not stress the framework so much.
By setting the scheduler job to a system job we can avoid that it is visible to the user.

I see that you are using the visible jobs to also terminate cron scripts. I would say that users should simply change the keyword to terminate such jobs. in future there will be the possibility to disable keywords from being parsed and executed at all, so users may disable the cron keyword entirely if they do not want it.

Hi Christian,

 > Hi Raphael,

Yes, we discussed this already. I just wanted to get feedback as fast as possible. So point is clear.

 > will spawn a new job automatically on the script.run() method.

 > the script engine instance) the scheduler Job would calculate the
 > next execution time and goes to sleep again.

So I will give it a second try. If I have problems I'll contact you.

Ok. Will change that.

Hopefully it's working as expected. :)
