So I implemented it with the Eclipse Jobs API and the code is now more complex, but it has also some advantages for the user, e.g. it's clear which script is running and we can show in which state the script is (Waiting for execution, execution, waiting for scheduling). It's also possible to cancel scripts. I think it's generally useful to run scripts with an Eclipse Job, especially if we talking about long running scripts.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Raphael,

I started the legal process for the cron-utils library. Before we can finish this topic we need to wait until this gets accepted and the orbit repo gets updated. Then we do not need to include cron-utils with ease at all, but consume it as a dependency.

Menawhile we could work a little on the implementation. You are currently using the Executor framework from java to spawn your execution threads. I would rather like to use the Eclipse Jobs API for that. 
What about waiting for the first corn keyword and the create an Eclipse system Job that query for the next script execution time, sleep until then and upon wakeup run the scripts. The script itself will spawn a new job automatically on the script.run() method. After script termination (you can register listeners for that on the script engine instance) the scheduler Job would calculate the next execution time and goes to sleep again.

Some general comments on code style: 
we use f qualifiers for fields, eg fExecutors isntead of executors. Therefore we need no this. qualifiers throughout the code.

Not all files do contain the copyright header so far. Please add them as each file needs them.

thanks for the contribution!

Patch Set 1:

> You probably mean it is *not complete*? Wrong is the current state,
 > because current code has NO enablement at all and so it is always
 > enabled, if looking into LaunchDescriptorTypeInfo and
 > LaunchConfigProviderInfo

Well, the descriptor is more complete than it was, yes, but the config provider will actually always fail. It never gets fed an IProject.

My point really is that we didn't implement this yet because it's going to be a fair amount of work to get right and we didn't have the time. Thanks for helping us get there!

 > So the first check for descriptor is same as in CoreBuildLaunchDescriptorType.getDescriptor(),
 > but where is the second for target?

It's here: CoreBuildLocalLaunchConfigProvider.supports(). It basically checks if the target is the Local one. For the descriptor, there should be an adapter to IProject so you could use a similar check.

BTW, it would be awesome to have some JUnits for this as well to make sure the enablement is working correctly.

Patch Set 5:

oh so there is a very interesting degenerate use case in the segment store benchmark, which shows us right here and there a problem: All 1000000 segments have the same length! so when sorting them by length, they are all returned, so each segment will bump the next one to the first queue, so each node will keep being read and ask for segment that are >= than a given one, but they all are!! So they keep being re-added to the queue and returned... I'm not even sure how this actually does not infinite loop. 

I'll push my latest version of this patch in case someone has inspiration and continue working on this.

I'm not exactly sure what this tests now. State Systems are pretty well tested in the state system plugin (full/single queries, etc). Here what we need to test _is_ the state provider, but not with that complicated data. We feed one simple event to the real state provider and make sure it does all and only the state changes it is supposed to do. And we need no more events than those that test exactly all the possible situations.

While I welcome getting rid of the generated test values, which is not really _unit_ tests, I'm not sure this really adds to the coverage. But you can convince me otherwise.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Some techinal/trivial remarks, but mostly what worries me a little is that this introduces the possibility for multiple backends to notify the ResourceSyncClient:
1. possibly in parallel (not sure ResourceSyncClient is thread-safe);
2. possibly from the UI thread (not a good idea, but as long as we open the door for arbitrary backends, we should be ready for this). Currently the EditingSessionWorkspaceListener used by the WorkspaceBackend is triggerd in a WorkerThread;
3. possibly multiple times for the same resource. Each backend is installed on the whole ResourceSet and has now way to know about/coordinate with other backends. If two or more try to handle the state of a specific Resource, possibly with inconsistent rules, it could lead to a mess.

For points 1 & 2, maybe the mechanism used by ResourceSyncClientNotifier (or something like it) should be lifted up into ResourceSyncClient directly.

For point 3, maybe I'm paranoid and this is only a theoretical issue that will never happen in practice. In the example attached to the bugzilla though, the code is careful to check:

   if (r.getURI() != null && MyProtocolResourceFactory.PROTOCOL_PREFIX.equals(r.getURI().scheme())) {

In a more open setting, I'm not sure it's wise to assume all backend implementers will have the proper checks and they will all be mutually exclusive.

That said, if these issues can be overcome (or prove to be non-issues), I'm all for the general idea of opening such an extension point.

Patch Set 3:

> Accessing a field and ignoring the getter is a no go. Also, not calling #isActive like done consistently falls into the same category.

As commented in the code, the goal of bypassing getter and isActive is to avoid having processors that effectively did not contribute to the completion session queried at all for errors.
It's indeed a not so clean code, and could probably be improved.

> I'm also not a friend of changing ContentAssistant to support error reporting in the async case. I would have to spend more time to understand why this is really needed.

It's needed because one contentAssistant can now have multiple processors, and multiple errors. So instead of just delegating to the only content-assist processor, the strategy becomes to aggregate output of the various available ones.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

So let's specify what we want:

* With interrupts, we can know where the interrupt comes from (Network, Disk, etc). Having a color for network/disk and such makes sense.

* Control flow view: Used to understand the states of threads/processes. It _is_ useful to know what it was interrupted by. But here, it means, "my process was interrupted by another process's network reception". Visually, in that view, the 'network' is a sub-state of 'interrupted' and could be drawn as the network color with a thick border of the interrupted color (real state/substate visualization)

* Critical path: Used to understand what was blocking a process of interest. Here, the Network/Disk/etc in the view means a link (edge) of that type between 2 elements of the trace, ie "the destination was waiting for network/disk message [from somewhere]". The concept of interrupt in that analysis appears like a trivial detail.

That means the LinuxStyles have different meaning for different analyses and views: they would share the colors, but maybe not the text. Having just 'Network' as text may become confusing when a pink rectangle doesn't mean the same thing in critical path view and control flow view.

I think the best way to experience this would be to port the critical path and execution graph to the linux styles (and os plugin). I can help you with that if you wish, but I recall you already have drafts for that ;-) So let's work on this now. Objective: April 28 12h34 :p

Hi Alex,
thanks for the fix!
While it solves the problem, your fix unfortunately has a side-effect that I'd like to avoid. If you select a match resource and run accept contained non-conflicting changes, it'll adapt the match resource to the diff group and runs the action on the diff group's children. However, if there are more than one resource matches, they are all children of the resource match and we would hence apply the action to all resource matches of the group.
Do you think there is a different way to obtain the children of the currently selected match resource node?
Thanks a lot!

3) Dependent code in platform (also JDT/CDT/PDE etc) should be identified) and a solution should be proposed (haven't checked yet what are the implications). If other plugins in platform use this internal code, we probably need a three-step approach: first, add the new API, second, update the rest of the platform to it, and finally remove the API. If the change affects too many components, we need to check if the removal can be done after the 4.7 release, even if this was internal code.

So I've -2 on this change now, which does not mean this is a dead-end, but just that we need to discuss the implications above on the bug first.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

With bug #481849 we're moving towards an approach with less "magic" where Sirius tries to approximate which MMs are needed, and instead encourage/force specifiers to be explicit in which MMs they need. If Sirius would continue to try to infer which MMs should be enabled based on completetly different sources, why would specifiers bother with configuring anything?

Anyway, the more global issue about which MMs are registered/visible at any point in time and in code is a very complex one. It's too late in the 4.0 cycle to change things in a way that may be reverted in a later version once we have thought more about it. I'll move this ticket to 4.1, where it may or may not be implemented, but at least it will be used as a source of concrete data to fuel the discussion about what should be done.

In addition, as mentioned in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=479726#c10, the code proposed here is only an approximation, true at a specific time but maybe not later.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

This approach still looks wrong to me. Introducing extra temporary states slows everything down and can introduce bugs by adding extra corner cases.

It should be perfectly valid to create a TabbedPropertySheetPage while the old part is still active. If that occurs, the TPSP should have had a call to setInput AFTER the new active part was assigned.

Either the workbench fired notifying about the active part change too early or the property view wasn't listening to the correct event -- neither requires the introduction of temporary states during a perspective switch.

Well, with this patch the problem shown in both videos in the bug is resolved. The selection signal no longer affects the trace editor and there is no loss of selection, if you replicate the use case that was shown.

The other discussion is about having time-synchronization off by default, or somewhat restricted to experiments. Without a pin feature it was previously not possible to opt-in to time synchronization so the design was to have it affect only overlapping traces, I don't think this is a bug. I feel this is something that should simply be tackled as part of the implementation of the pin feature.

Patch Set 4:

Marc, do you have a general feeling if this is a good or bad idea. I was very frustrated to find out, when debugging Bug 506382, that if the exception had not been swallowed I would potentially saved a lot of time. In the case of filing Bug 506382 I was a "normal" user, using EPP package, no -ea or tracing. I was preparing a demo of CDT and all I could see was the memory browser's new feature were not working. With no exceptions I spent quite a while trying to figure out what was wrong with my setup rather than quickly identifying that CDT had and NPE.

Thanks for taking the time to comment. --Jonah

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

> I think the idea of this change is ok.
 > The approach of making error information easy to find for users is
 > similar to the decision to have the 'gdb traces' on by default all
 > this time; it makes us faster to resolve bugs.

OK, I will progress with this then.


 > It's not clear to me what you want to do with all the TODOs, but
 > the part about logging the error all the time is ok with me.

These were me documenting (bookmarking) for my purposes. I will not be merging those changes.

I was trying to understand all the places in the code that did this sort of pattern correctly or not:

    try {
       query.get(); or callable.get()
    } catch (ExecutionException e) {
    } catch other things

In the end there were 100 or so places in CDT that silently ignores ExecutionException without even a comment, and I tagged the places that happened. Additionally I tagged some places for me to revisit that made other assumptions about the ExecutionException, like its cause was of a specific type.

As you are on board with the general concept, I will aim to finish the change and submit with no work in progress bits. I'll let you know when I do so you can review the final intention.

Thanks!
Jonah

Patch Set 2:

Final note for now, this change is dependent on another commit and neither of them are based on master. The gerrit flow is to change the same commit again and again (by amending it). Also it would be helpful if you rebased your change to master. For example these commands may represent one update session:

    $ git checkout <change>
    $ git fetch origin
    $ git rebase origin/master # to bring your changes up to date
    $ ... make edits ...
    $ git add <your new edits>
    $ git commit --amend
    $ git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master # to update gerrit.

I hope that was helpful.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2 Verified-1

The script as of patchset 2 will change the version of plugins in their pom.xml file,  if they happen to have the same version as what we are mathing.

We can easily notice this when the build fails because the MANIFEST.MF of that plugin won't match.  In that case, we need to revert part of the pom.xml.

Making the script smart enough to handle this is non-trivial because the pom.xml file of feature must update the version, but not the pom.xml file of plugins, so I can't simply look for pom.xml.

I'm going to leave this alone for now.
There was talk of going to pom-less builds, which could simplify this anyway.

Patch Set 14: Code-Review-2

There is a synchronization limitation in the current latest GDB (7.12): MI commands that use "--thread" and "--frame" parameters have the side-effect of switching the current thread/frame focus, in GDB, without the frontend being notified. This happens whether the synchronization is enabled or not. 

This interferes with this patch, when the user choses to disable the synchronization, and virtually any DV selection will change the GDB focus, by the side-effect described above. So, for now, we're better not letting the user disable syncronization. When the GDB limitation is lifted, we can bring back this patch.

Patch Set 1:

> This patch doesn't fix the problem.

That's very strange. I just tried with a fresh install of a Neon.1 Java package. I got the error as expected, then installed a local EGit build with the patch, and afterwards was able to clone and push via HTTP with authentication. As expected, I got EGit's authentication dialog in the clone wizard, and then both the clone and the subsequent push (with credentials from the secure storage) worked fine. I ran the same procedure again in a remote-debug session just to confirm, and the EGit Authenticator was left intact by MPC as I would have expected.

In any case, since we have now requested a simrel respin to ship the fix in MPC via automatic updates, I would suggest to abandon this change.

Patch Set 1:

I think this is off-topic, but just to be thorough: One thing I did notice was that when cloning the repository without having credentials in secure storage, I got the EGit credentials dialog twice in the course of the Clone wizard, even though I chose to store my credentials: once when first listing the remote branches, and then again during the fetch after completing the wizard.

But I verified that the same happened for me even in an Eclipse SDK installation without MPC present, so I guess it is an unrelated issue in EGit.

Patch Set 3:

ScriptType instance is required to parse script.
Is there a way to get ScriptType instance of script using Script instance?

Currently I am getting scriptType using title.
Doing so, I am not able to check for scripts called using include(URL) command since include command is executed directly using stream and no title is involved.

So, for now, for those checks for which scriptType or title is not available, they will be allowed to execute.

If there is no other way of getting ScriptType, we can explicitly gate such entry points by adding security checks such that scriptType is specified.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> ScriptType instance is required to parse script.
 > Is there a way to get ScriptType instance of script using Script
 > instance?
 > 
 > Currently I am getting scriptType using title.
 > Doing so, I am not able to check for scripts called using
 > include(URL) command since include command is executed directly
 > using stream and no title is involved.
 > 
 > So, for now, for those checks for which scriptType or title is not
 > available, they will be allowed to execute.
 > 
 > If there is no other way of getting ScriptType, we can explicitly
 > gate such entry points by adding security checks such that
 > scriptType is specified.

Another solution can be to avoid language specific comment codes to parse file. For this we can add getSignaureInfo without checks for comments to SignatureHelper class.

With this patch, of user has specified to "allow script execution of local files that do not contain signature", and file does not contain signature, script will be allowed to execute, but if script contains signature, it will be checked. Same is the case for remote scripts.

Regarding user popups, I have added user popups within SignatureCheck class to get user response regarding script execution. Once popups are registered to ScriptEngines, we can shift to that.

Patch Set 5:

Here, any command of type URL will be treated as remote and File will be treated as local (out of workspace). IFile and dynamic code segments will be excluded from check.

In include method of EnvironmentModule, instead of passing url.openStream to inject method, now I am passing url so that we can get URL string during check for signature, so that we can distinguish it from dynamic code segments. I am not completely sure about all consequences of last step. It is working nicely for signature checks.

Patch Set 1:

Hi,

thanks a lot for your feedback.

I just checked some of the internal classes affected by this change.
It appears that the origin of the superfluous exceptions is in the public packages.
The changes to the internal classes appear to be just as a consequence of removing the superfluous exceptions in the public classes.

Hence, I think it is best to wait until it is safe to also change the public classes for merging this change.
I will leave this change open for now such that it can be rebased and merged once it is safe to do so.



Thanks again and cheers,

Ruediger

Patch Set 1:

Removing checked exceptions breaks source compatibility, but not binary compatibility [1]. I think this is why the Eclipse API tool does not report it as an API break.

We would have to decide if binary compatibility is sufficient. IMO if the tool says it's fine it should be fine, because we have a reference. I am quite sure there are other places where source compatibility was broken and we just did not notice it. But I'm open to suggestions.

The changes in the "internal" packages however should be perfectly safe. Ruediger, if you would like to respin this patch (either on top of this one, or a completely new patch) to only include the API changes in internal packages, that I am pretty sure we could get that in right away.

Thanks!

[1] See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Evolving_Java-based_APIs_2 , as well as the corresponding note.

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

@Igor: I agree that high-quality bug reports are a lot of work. Still, I think this alternative route to report submission is a valuable offer to users (who are often themselves Eclipse committers -- or at least dedicated enough to have an eclipse.org account).

In particular, after you have create the bug this way, you can use the new Mylyn task to conveniently attach projects or screenshots to the bug, thus making it easier for you to reproduce.

So, I don't really see any harm being done, as this feature targets exactly the same user base (eclipse.org account holders) and just gives them an alternative (and IMHO more convenient, but YMMV) way to submit bug reports.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

I have been thinking about this and coming back to it again and again. I can finally say that I am not comfortable that this is good enough. Fundamentally if someone extends GdbLaunch and GdbAdapterFactory and does not install the adapters properly their code is broken.

At the moment in the example with the GdbExtendedAdapterFactory it happens to all work OK because ISuspendTrigger is registered properly as on the the types GdbExtendedLaunch can adapt to and that type is one of the first ones to be adapter to. If an extender did not register one of the types that was used early on, their GdbExtendedAdapterFactory would never be used and their own session adapters would never be loaded. However the worst case is that the first time that the GdbExtendedAdapterFactory is accessed is not at the beginning of a session and in that case the behviour changes for undetermined reasons.

Therefore, I think that change 69923 should be accepted as it fixes the immediate problem of the current example being wrong.

Additionally, if extenders want to make sure that their class adapts to new types that come along in the future, then they should use a line like this in their extended GdbAdapterFactory constructor:

    Platform.getAdapterManager().registerAdapters(this, <their extended>GdbLaunch.class);

That will register programatically the adapter factory against all the types in GdbAdapterFactory.getAdapterList().

Patch Set 3:

I am updating change 69923 to add in the Platform.getAdapterManager().registerAdapters(this, <their extended>GdbLaunch.class); plus some documentation on the subject.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I've pushed the updated patch.
The problem with asynchronous execution is ... that it is asynchronous - e.g. if the job needs more time to calculate new repository, but selection changes in the meantime, clients may still see the "old" repository.

I think the RepositorySourceProvider has currently following problems:
1) as of today (in-sync) it is invoked on any selection change. This will be a big pain for everyone who uses IDE, has lot of repositories there and don't use gitflow at all.
2) if it is changed as proposed here (a-sync), it will sometimes deliver wrong data. Nothing one want to have.

So while I understand the original intent of introducing this code, I think the solution should be slightly different. I'm thinking about it right now.

Patch Set 4:

So now the computation is in the background but the tester (and menus) will always see the right value if requested - they will need of course wait the first time, but at least it can cancel this.

I've disabled computation because of changed text selections now - this is an overkill. Selections in explorers etc will still work.

I'm still wondering if we should move this code to the gitflow plugin.

Patch Set 9:

Sorry about the late reply; I was travelling.

I'm not sure this is the right approach.

1. I think something is fundamentally wrong if the property tester needs to know the source provider. (Yes, I see this has changed slightly in the follow-up change, but basically only the access to the RepositorySourceProvider has been hidden in a utility class.)
2. The text selection originally was included to have correct enablement of GitFlow submenu entries is the context menu in an open editor. To avoid that we re-evaluate the property tester on each text selection change, the RepositorySourceProvider was introduced. Now that we don't handle the text selection anymore, we wouldn't need any of this at all. We could just revert back to commit a612318d (before the RepositorySourceProvider was introduced) and simply remove the text selection handling in SelectionPropertyTestser.getRepository().
3. Not handling the text selection breaks the context menu in open editors. I don't get any GitFlow entries at all anymore. Yes, I realize that this is fixed in the follow-up change I0bc7aee.

The RepositorySourceProvider was supposed to do the cheap part (getting the repository from the selection), and enable us to do the expensive part (accessing the repo config) only if the repo really changed, which isn't the case as long as only the text selection within an editor changes. The assumption was that getting the repo from the selection was indeed cheap. We use that same mechanism elsewhere, and it never caused any performance problems. It's used in the lightweight decorator, and also in the ResourceStatePropertyTester and in the EGit UI SelectionPropertyTester (resourcesSingleRepository).

So, the real question is why is getting the repo from the selection in the RepositorySourceProvider suddenly expensive, when it isn't in other places?

Maybe it's because the RepositorySourceProvider gets instantiated rather early, and the projects are not mapped yet. That's what I read from Andrey's stack trace. If so, there might be ways to mitigate this:

* "Activating" the RepositorySourceProvider only once the rest of Eclipse startup is done. Let it return a null entry initially, and switch it on only once the workbench has been restored. At that point presumably the projects are mapped... I don't know off-hand how we'd detect "workbench has been restored", though.
* Alternatively, start a background job as soon as the EGit UI plugin is activated to asynchronusly try to map projects/restore the GitProviders, and hope that by the time the RepositorySourceProvider gets called, the projects are mapped. Perhaps it's even good enough to just try to load the project persistent properties in the background -- I didn't look into what gets ached there when and how.
* Alternatively, let the RepositorySourceProvider not handle text selections, but let it additionally listen to active part changes, and whenever an editor becomes active, start listening to changes to the editor input, then determine the repo from the editor input. Again, I don't know off-hand how we'd listen to either (active part changes and editor input changes), but I guess Eclipse has the mechanisms we'd need to do that. I'm also not sure if listening to editors is enough -- what about views?

Off-hand, all this job logic here strikes me as rather complicated -- even if in the end, with the follow-up change, it appears to work.

Patch Set 9:

> So, the real question is why is getting the repo from the selection
 > in the RepositorySourceProvider suddenly expensive, when it isn't
 > in other places?

Have updated my Eclipse now also to Mars.1/EGit 4.2.0.201601080847. I do _not_ get any UI monitoring reports, neither on startup nor on selection changes nor on text input.

@Andrey:
* Do you consistently and reproducibly get these UI "freeze" reports?
* When exactly do you get them? On what UI operations?
* What's the freeze time reported?

Is there anything special about your workspace? Such as workspace located on a slow (non-local?) disk? Huge number of projects and/or repos?

I really would like to get at the bottom of this and understand exactly why you are getting UI freeze messages for something that in past experience seemed like a fairly cheap operation.

Patch Set 9:

> I really would like to get at the bottom of this and understand
 > exactly why you are getting UI freeze messages for something that
 > in past experience seemed like a fairly cheap operation.

I now got one such UI freeze report. Happened when I started Eclipse and started doing things before the JDT initialization was done.

JDT initialization always takes an inane amount of time for me, and generally starting to type or invoking context menus or doing just about anything before it's done is a bad idea. Used to be much better in Kepler...

Anyway, in the assorted stack traces I got, I see two things:

1. I see a conflict between JDT setting a persistent property (source attachment) and EGit trying to read a persistent property (team provider ID). If those properties happen to be in the same Bucket, JDT may block EGit.

2. The RepositorySourceProvider may try to access the persistent property concurrently with the GitLightweightDecorator or even ActionHandlers' isEnabled().

Not sure what we could do about (1). But (2) could perhaps be solved by making sure that action handlers don't try to re-determine the repo themselves but use the one determined by the RepositorySourceProvider. (I.e., similar to what the follow-up change to this one does.) That would at least reduce the contention on that persistent property bucket. However, doing so needs probably some more changes. See comment on the follow-up change.

Patch Set 1:

The problem comes from the DefaultDiffEngine which has specific comportment: if we have an ancestor, the values of the created diffs are the ancestor value, and if the ancestor is null, the values of the diffs are the left and right elements values.
By using the same comportment for each case we might have a null value in some case (the ancestor have a non null value and this property has been unset on both left and right side for example) but its is preferable for developers and users to display a null in some case and to have always the same comportment (which is having a diff containing the latest value of the element).

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for working on this!

What I don't like about this change is the configuration part. So it would show the "Push Branch" wizard. Problems:

* There's not enough context to know which repository it is about.
* The labels are wrong ("Push Branch").
* The user can deselect "Configure upstream", in which case the repository is still not configured after the wizard is finished.
* The "Force" option doesn't have any effect.

I recommend undoing the configuration parts of this change:

* Just push the repositories that are configured, and skip the others.
* In the result dialog, list the unconfigured repositories so that it can be seen what the problem with them was.
* Leave the special case to use "Push Branch..." for a single repository.

Configuring them one by one is not really more work, and in the individual wizard the user will be able to confirm/correct the result.

(By the way, can you work on multi fetch next? ;])

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(14 comments)

- multi-push is only enabled if git toolbar is activated, otherwise "Push to Upstream" is disabled in all menus
- if there's an error the error message is shown in a single line which is pretty hard to read, see http://i.imgur.com/0dJ3rDU.png
- if there's no error the "Errors occurred" column shows "No Errors", I rename this column to "Status message" and show the summary status line from the details page, e.g. "master -> master [up to date]" since this is the most valuable information if push succeeded.
- if there's nothing to push I have to wait a long time and always one out of 2 push operations has a failed status, I suspect something goes wrong in case there's no commit to push for multiple selected repositories

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This break EGit authentication for http(s):

When a request is sent initially without credentials in order to find out which authentication the server wants the server responds with status code "401 - Unauthorized" to request authentication. Then HttpUrlConnection asks the authenticator for credentials and that raises a dialog so that EGit/JGit can't use their own credentials provider which would return what was configured in EGit or is stored in the secure store ;-(

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-2

(4 comments)

One significant change (regression even if confirmed) in behavior with this is that previously, the check on navigation tool (precondition & co) was made on each refresh() of the decorator edit part. With this patch, it will only be done when a representation is created or removed. If a semantic change makes the condition change, the decorator will not be updated.

Example (not tested): I have a diagram D1 with semantic element A visible on it. I create a new diagram D2 on B, which is navigable from A, but only if B has some property, which it has not at this point (for the sake of the example, "A can navigate to B only if B contains at least one C"). At this point we don't create a decorator for A. Go on B, create some Cs. Go back to A: no representation has been created, so we do not refresh the decorator, and I still can't navigate from A to B.

This is all hypothetical, from my understanding of the code just reading it. I may be wrong. If I'm not, we can't have this regression.

Therefore, having the option to inherit it from the container is important.

> A fix would allow both scenarios and also show the current encoding, similar to the encoding UI in the properties.

Patch Set 1:

I don't understand what you mean...

As far as I understand, technically there are the following possible values to set as content type's charset:
1. null - the pre-defined value in the extension defining the content type
2. empty string - inherited from container
3. specific value - UTF-8, US-ASCII, etc.

On the proposed UI #1 is covered by the Default radio button. #2 and #3 are covered by the Other radio button - I plan to have a "Inherited from container" value in the drop down.

I designed the UI this way, because in a previous comment you said that #1 is very important. If I just have "Inherited from container" and "Other" radio buttons then #1 is not covered.

Take a look at the existing UI for changing the encoding on the Resource properties page. We don't want to allow the empty string in the drop down. It should only contain and allow valid encodings. The tricky part here is the word "default" which has two meanings:
- the default to be used by the file
- the (original)default on the preference page


Some possible solutions:

[ ] Define text file encoding for this content type:

  ( ) Other: [drop down]

or

Text file encoding:
( ) [drop down]               [Restore Default Encoding]    
( ) Inherited from container

Patch Set 3:

Our usecase is strange, I admit. The goal is to have an o.e.remote which is visible in launchbar and NOT visible in the core o.e.remote UI (view, pref page, etc). 

Unfortunately, an argument could be made that no matter how we do this, it wouldn't make sense.  If the o.e.remote is marked as 'not visible' then it shouldn't be visible in o.e.remote OR in launchbar. 

If it simply has no UI service, then it wouldn't be visible in EITHER of the two. 

But obviously our requirement is that it IS visible in o.e.launchbar, that it has custom icons based on internal details, and that it's NOT visible via o.e.remote standard UI. 

If you're wondering why our requirements are so... strange... its because we didnt even want to use o.e.remote to display our 'target' for launchbar, but the launchbar API *only* allows IRemoteConnection objects in the third box. 

Our o.e.remote provides 0 services and essentially does nothing except wrap an org.eclipse.wst.server IServer object. The only reason we're even implementing it at all is to get a custom target into launchbar. 

If o.e.launchbar had a more open interface for what could be a target, OR if it was able to search more places than just org.eclipse.remote.internal.core.RemoteServicesManager for instances of IRemoteConnection (ie if we could somehow create them on-the-fly only for use in launchbar) then we wouldn't need to do any of this.

Patch Set 3:

> what's the harm of making it visible in the remote UI

It clutters up the UI, and can confuse users. They will expect to be able to interact with the thing. They don't expect that we simply created it because the launchbar requires an o.e.remote object. 

I suppose it's not 'horrible' in the preference page, where the stuff is sorted by types and a specific type can simply be ignored. But in the view, things are all together, and you end up with a list cluttered by unusable objects. 

I honestly still believe that the best idea is to open up launchbar to not require o.e.remote objects ;)

Patch Set 3:

>  Well, servers are remote objects. You'll want to switch to o.e.remote eventually anyway.

Yes, we'll want to switch to o.e.remote from RSE, to represent the individual connections "underpinning" our server adapter. But we don't want to represent our entire wst.server server-adapter as an o.e.remote.... because then we'd need a "Server-Adapter" o.e.remote instance, as well as the various "ssh Server-Adapter" and "telnet Server-Adapter" o.e.remote connections.  It makes sense for us to represent the ssh or telnet or other connections in o.e.remote. It doesn't really make sense for us to represent the entire server adapter as an o.e.remote.... that's what wst.server is for...  and the only reason we're doing that is to get it visible as a target in launchbar. 

> After all the proposed changes, I'm getting concerned about the API getting more complex than it needs to. I've been very focused on keeping it clean. If there are other ways to do this with the existing API, I'd rather do that.

The problem here is that you'd be going on assumptions.  If you make a decision that a connection that can't be interacted with shouldn't be shown, you'll similarly get a complaint by someone who wants to make a remote for their own uses, have the user not able to change it, but still have it show up in the list They may register non-standard services on it, or add actions to it in the common navigator / view, and so still expect it to be visible. 

The use-cases are real. This isn't just me requesting new API for no reason.

Patch Set 3:

If you really want to keep the launchbar API smaller, I can move all the added methods from ILaunchBarManager into IAuthorizedLaunchBarManager.  But I still feel the separation and cleanup and added comments make the code much more understandable. 

Again, this specific patch isn't because I'm requesting new public API.  It's more an 'internal cleanup' and I wouldn't mind if all those new methods went in the internal interface rather than the public one...  If that's what you prefer, I'd be glad to move those methods around.

Patch Set 1:

I like this feature. I think we should do the same as native git. Native git has "git remote rename <old> <new>". It renames remote tracking branches (e.g. from refs/remotes/origin/master to refs/remotes/new/master) and it updates the config. See here:

  [/tmp/dondalfi (master)]$ git branch -a
  * master
    remotes/origin/Adder
    remotes/origin/HEAD -> origin/master
    remotes/origin/Multiplyer
    remotes/origin/master
    remotes/origin/test
    remotes/origin/tmpA
  [/tmp/dondalfi (master)]$ git checkout -b test origin/Adder
  Branch test set up to track remote branch Adder from origin.
  Switched to a new branch 'test'
  [/tmp/dondalfi (test)]$ git remote rename origin new
  [/tmp/dondalfi (test)]$ git branch -a
    master
  * test
    remotes/new/Adder
    remotes/new/HEAD -> new/master
    remotes/new/Multiplyer
    remotes/new/master
    remotes/new/test
    remotes/new/tmpA
  [/tmp/dondalfi (test)]$ cat .git/config
  [core]
          repositoryformatversion = 0
          filemode = false
          bare = false
          logallrefupdates = true
          symlinks = false
          ignorecase = true
          hideDotFiles = dotGitOnly
  [remote "new"]
          url = https://chalstrick@github.com/chalstrick/dondalfi
          fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/new/*
  [branch "master"]
          remote = new
          merge = refs/heads/master
  [branch "test"]
          remote = new
          merge = refs/heads/Adder

Notice that it will also update the "remote" value for a branch which is tracking a remote branch.

Now to the part you may not like: Can't we do that in JGit. Normally we add functionality which is there also in native git into the JGit library. This way also other tools apart from EGit using JGit can use this feature. I suggest to add a RemoteRenameCommand to org.eclipse.jgit.api which allows to rename remotes.

Patch Set 1:

Do we want to have two separate register-handling services (and advertise both) or is it an implementation detail?  If it is about design and modularity, maybe we can look into using the same pattern as for the GDBPatternMatchingExpressions service?

The idea would be to have a single advertised service to handle registers (GDBManagedRegisterGroups) which would then delegate to MIRegisters (or maybe even GDBRegisters) whenever necessary.  The pattern is similar to overriding MIRegisters service, except it de-couples things in such a way that you can override both MIRegisters (and even GDBManagedRegisterGroups) while keeping GDBManagedRegisterGroups as the first entry point.

I don't know if that patterns fits well in the goals of this patch, but it would make the publishing of the register services a little cleaner.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1 Verified+1

Hi Hussein,

Sorry it took me so long to respond.  Okay, I am not sure whether your solution works.  My concerns:

- Having a "replace" field in each filter element is cumbersome, for two reasons:

- (1) Having a "replace" field in each search criteria feels strange and non-standard.  I think a better approach would be to duplicate what Eclipse does: Clicking on "Replace..." opens a new dialog that allows the search String to be modified and the replace String to be defined.  This would allow to first step to filter the affected elements, and in a second step to decide how the affected elements will be modified.

- (2) The second problem with the current approach is space, as the text fields become too small.

- In the current implementation, replacing a String replaces the complete String, rather than the matched substring.

- The current implementation does not seem to function for XHTML.

So let me reject this for the time being.  I am not sure whether my suggestions here will lead to the "best" solution - we can also discuss the proposed solution on the dev-List.

Thanks, Michael

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

This appears to fix the specific case it was intended to. I say "appears" because when I tested it it worked, but I can't understand the code well enough to be confident that it works in all cases. 

Unfortunately, this completely breaks comment navigation when there are only comments on 1 side.

To repeat my earlier suggestion from patch set 5, I think we should just swap the 2 lines to fix it in the simple case for now. What's in master works pretty well but it's becoming clear that it's going to be difficult to get it 100% perfect and I'm afraid that making changes of this size this late in the release will end up breaking more than it fixes.

It seems to me that the code is more complex than it needs to be. Instead of doing an elaborate caluculation to find the next left and right and then using complicated logic to choose one of them, we could just maintain a list of ComparePositions sorted by offset and side, one for each annotation. Then, choosing the next/previous annotation would be a simple matter of finding our current position in the list. I definitely don't think we should make such a major change for this release, but it might be worth exploring for the next release instead of continuing to iterate on the current implementation.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

Ok, so here's the issue that I have with the code. It's just not clear what's happening. If we can't grok it just by looking at it then we can't hope to understand and verify that it's doing what we expect.

It could be working perfectly well as a consequence of trial and error, but just until we get to the next error. As Sam suggested in Patch Set 7 we really need to fix the code, particularly calculateNextAnnotation so that it makes _semantic_ sense -- what we're trying to do is complex, and we need the semantics to represent that.

What are all of these special cases for? I think we might need to actual have a higher order representation to do this right; not to get carried away, but maybe a simple state machine or something or a Position Compare like Sam suggests. At the very least  we should have named methods so we know what the code is attempting to do.

Patch Set 10:

Also, there should be a number of other opportunities to improve the code based on the sorted list approach.

"If you're using the interface so that you can have a bunch of objects of various types held only by a reference to the interface, then you might need to expose dispose() as well on the interface to allow them to be disposed generically."

Thanks again!

Marc

The visualizer changes look okay to me; a few minor inline comments. Someone more familiar with the DSF side of things should review those changes.

Patch Set 3:

> In your comment about interface cleanliness regarding the > dispose() method in IVisualizerModelDataSource: Would you > elaborate a bit about what you meant?

> Is it the idea of having a cleanup method in the interface...

Right, ideally an interface should be only the behavior that's essential to the interface. Now, there's nothing saying an interface can't have a cleanup method, e.g. "close()" on an IO interface, or "release()" on an object
that holds some resource, but "dispose()" here didn't seem essential as part of this particular interface definition.

(BTW, I have no problem with "dispose()" as the name of
the method, since I'm where the usage came from!)

> Another thought: In the case of the DSFSessionState
> implementation of the interface, calling dispose() is
> probably not necessary, as long as
> RemoveAllServiceEventListeners() is called. is that
> perhaps what you meant?

Welll... it's more like if you have a list of the objects
in question via a "real" reference through which dispose()
can be called, then dispose() doesn't need to be on the
interface. If you're using the interface so that you can have a bunch of objects of various types held only by a reference to the interface, then you might need to expose dispose() as well on the interface to allow them to be disposed generically. (Though in that case, technically the
dispose() method would want to be on an IDisposable interface that IVisualizerModelDataSource extends. Or would that be _too_ C#? ;-)

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

BTW the fixes look fine to me -- thanks!

Patch Set 4:

> One question: it happens that there is an existing IDisposable interface (defined in package org.eclipse.ui.services), but it was meant for something not quite related ("services that make themselves available through the IAdaptable mechanism").

> Technically that interface has what I need (i.e. dispose() method), but my use of it seems a bit outside of what was intended. Do you think I should instead create my own IDisposable? 

[WRS] Right, you don't want to create a package dependency just to reuse similar functionality. In an ideal world, there'd be a more "utils"-ish place where a generic IDisposable interface would live, which everyone could safely reference. For now, I'd add a local IDisposable interface, and it can be retargeted to a common definition later if one ever becomes available.

Patch Set 3:

I've talked with Andreas about this 2 weeks ago.

He wasn't happy back then with Olav's ClassDocumentationBuilder, as Andreas wanted to move to a more DOCTYPE like creation of HTML Output (like W3C-DOM). So he introduced a draft for a new alternative HTML Builder (see other change). Olav and me rather wanted to use a lib for things like this (if really needed), instead of re-implementing it.

However, current status is:
It *could* be that the JDK 8 Javadoc API provides already a functionality for this, as they offer the new "-doclint"
feature, which does a syntax and semantic check on HTML Code you wrote in Javadoc comments.
This needs to be further invested, as it could solve us many problems here. Unfortunately, I didn't had the time to do this yet.
And to be honest: To look into the JDK 8 Javadoc API is >1.0 on my roadmap, I didn't high prioritized these two patch sets, neither introduced them (but ofc, would be happy about it ;) ).

So, Andreas want to leave this open for now, they don't do harm to anyone. But maybe move them to a gerrit draft branch? (And so, create one if this is possible without paperwork).

Patch Set 10:

During the writing of this interface I thought about this too. But the following things come into my mind and so I decided not to do it (for the moment :-))

*) The need of the service is just to restore a persisted/dehydrated MPerspective state and not to do all the magic the EModelService#resetPerspectiveModel() does.
*) It should also act as a kind of abstraction layer for the persistence logic (e.g.: another add-on could for example use a DB to store and restore a MPerspecitve, or an add-on which uses a file per perspective state to store)
*) (and last but not least) I just want to try if this ideas finds some followers.

If others want to enrich the methods of this interface too, I'm happy to add your suggestions.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Hi Muhammad. Many thanks for the numerous test cases. I have commented on some of them inline.

However, I think for the moment there are too many test cases; maybe it would be easier to start with a smaller, simple set of test cases first (makes it easier to review and comprehend all the scenarios) and try to come up with an implementation that fulfills the easy cases first.

Maybe just the one rule: prefix is better than subword.

We can then use these test cases to work on the implementation/discuss how to apply dynamic programming to it.

Speaking of which, I was envisioning the following two-dimensional array that you fill in bit by bit: in position (x,y) you have the maximum score achievable by matching the subword s.substring(0, x) to the method name m.substring(0, y). Of course, if x grows by one you have one more subword char to fit in (and thus gain potentially a higher score) and if y grows you have one more character of freedom to optimally place your x-character subword within the y-character method name.

Patch Set 2:

If we are looking for a quick and dirty hack, the safest one is probably to just filter out duplicate bases in cases like this.

Patch Set 1:

I was wrong about the index dropping duplicate definition.  I've made this mistake before and when I go back to check I remember that it is only in the AST (setDefinition overwrites the existing field), which is valid.  The index does correctly handle duplicates in all cases I looked at.

However, that investigation got me looking deeply into how specializations are stored in the index.  I'm going to update this bug with my observations and thoughts.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I've updated the bug with what I found from my most recent investigation.  I now longer think the problem is just this handling of the base classes.  Instead I think the problem is that only a single binding is created for all partial template specializations.

The last comment in the bug shows that when there are two identical class definitions (in different translation units) we get two bindings.  However, when there are two partial specializations (in different translation units) there is only a single binding.

Patch Set 2:

As I pointed out in an earlier comment "I was wrong about the index dropping duplicate definition. I've made this mistake before and when I go back to check I remember that it is only in the AST (setDefinition overwrites the existing field), which is valid. The index does correctly handle duplicates in all cases I looked at."

Further, this patch is not fully correct, but it is wrong to say that it is worse that the current behaviour.

If there are two partial templ. specs right now, then the index will have the equivalent of:

    class Te<T*> : public B1, public B1 {};

Which is obviously non-sensical.  Why would a class have more than one of the same class as a base class.  This patch will create the more sane binding:

    class Te<T*> : public B1 {};

The right solution of having a binding with B2 as a base is missing from both solutions.

Patch Set 13:

Section 2.5.3 of RFC 4291 says

 The loopback address must not be used as the source address in IPv6  packets that are sent outside of a single node.
So we cannot set the interface as the loopback address(::1)
 Hence the error

Patch Set 13:

You get an error whenever you

Patch Set 13:

Whenever you try to send a packet with source address as loopback address you will get an error as the implementation is done according to RFC 4291. This applies only for ipv6  not for ipv4.

The instructions are still not clear to me. Here's what I tried:

* in the editor, change "pick" to "edit", so rebase will stop
* in Eclipse, make sure the staging view is refreshed
* click "Abort"

Patch Set 1:

I see, the problem is that the rebase hasn't even been started yet, and therefore aborting it only changes the repository state, but not the index diff nor refs.

Hm, I'm not sure what to do. I don't like firing refschanged for all commands, as it results in unnecessary work in IndexDiffCacheEntry.

Patch Set 3: Verified; I would prefer that you didn't submit this; IP review completed

(8 inline comments)

I noticed that this change breaks some JUnit tests.  Namely org.eclipse.cdt.tests.dsf.gdb.tests.LaunchConfigurationAndRestartTest

The reason is that the case of a \n is not handled anymore.  It may sound far fetched, but it actually is not because users can easily put arguments in two different lines in the launch Arguments tab.  I recall there was a bug about this but I cannot find it.

Also, I'm bothered by the change in DebugNewProcessSequence though.  We are changing the behavior of MIGDBSetArgs.  From what I understand, MIGDBSetArgs should be passed a single string of arguments, to give it "as-is" to GDB.  We should not be using an array of arguments.  Therefore, I think we should add a new

MIGDBSetArgs(IMIContainerDMContext, String)

and corresponding

public ICommand<MIInfo> createMIGDBSetArgs(IMIContainerDMContext dmc, String arguments)

we should also deprecate
MIGDBSetArgs(IMIContainerDMContext, String[])
since it should not be used anymore, and the one in CommandFactory.

In org.eclipse.cdt.debug.gdbjtag.core:
GDBJtagDSFFinalLaunchSequence should be updated not to use the newly deprecated createMIGDBSetArgs(IMIContainerDMContext, String[])

Patch Set 1: Verified; I would prefer that you didn't submit this; IP review completed

The problem with this approach is that by adding the bean during the doStart, is that you will not see it in a dump when the handler is stopped.

Also the problem is that the handler is already dumped by the parent class by explicitly calling getHandlers(), so simply adding the bean will mean that it get's dumped twice.

The addBean call should be done in setHandler and it has to be made to work with AbstractHandlerContainer

Patch Set 8:

> What do you think about the following alternative approach: An action is added to Repositories View that allows the user to unlock the Index. This implies some extra clicks for the user but it avoids the problems that Jobs send a UI and that operations need to be wrapped by LockOperation. I think the extra clicks are acceptable because hanging index locks do not occur often.

I am unsure if adding an action to the repository menu that is very advanced and (hopefully) rarely used is the right move.

If if it was moved to an action, it would still require adding a custom dialog to inform them of the situation since the current dialog is the default one for any exception that is thrown and isn't very helpful about what caused the situation and how it can be remedied.  So if a custom dialog is needed to inform them of the situation then it seems better to have them act on it from that dialog.

I have updated the change to no longer do the prompt in a syncExec so it won't be holding any locks now when the user is informed.

Another remaining piece is whether the lock deletion should be scheduled in a job with a scheduling rule that ensures no other jobs could be running that are performing operations that require an index lock.

Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I am not sure if this approach is compliant to Eclipse guide lines.
Is it a good behavior to send dialogs to a user when executing a Job?
What is the result of a job if the operation failed and the user removed the lock afterwards? If the result is failure then the user will get an additional error pop-up from Eclipse. If the result is success, then the result is a bit strange.

Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I don't see why we need this as we already support Team Project Sets.

If you want to clone multiple repositories using a file as input you may use "Import... > Team > Team Project Set" instead. This functionality was added recently. Team Project Set files can be created using "Export... > Team > Team Project Set".

In order to prevent such surprises it maybe a good idea to first file an enhancement bug and discuss your idea with the community.

This proposal looks unfinished when looking at the source code. Think twice before pushing code which isn't ready for review as this wastes the time of reviewers. If you really think you need feedback on work in progress then mark it with [RFC] in the commit header.

Patch Set 2:

I see, you need first to discuss what you want to offer as EGit API.

You are right, that it is untransparent to the user, if somebody can change the resources without the knowledge of a user. In the finalizeCommit phase, I am interacting with another system. By this interaction it is possible that some local files change and for my need I _must_ commit these changed files as well.

Maybe we can show the user in that case a second dialog, so that all files for commit are viewable to the user. If the user does not like the modified commit, than the commit process may be canceled.
But I need to interact on the selected resources, so putting this phase before showing the first dialog is not an option for me.

If you do not want to let the class âCommitOperationâ be accessible, than I need to add an additional âcall-backâ method to the CommitObserver. The CommitObserver should be notified if the commit was successful or not.

You proposed a data container class with the information needed for commit which could be manipulated by the Observer.
It would be great if a CommitObserver-Developer would not need to handle with âindexedFilesâ and âuntrackedFilesâ, only with the files that should be committed. Meta-information should be handled as a black box (in the container or later).
Would you expect that I should write such a container? I could try to do this if wanted, but at the moment I am not so sure about the requirements for the container. Maybe we should discuss this before.

Cheers Adrian
